In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: When that Aprile with his shoures soote
The drought of Marche / had perced the roote
And bathed every vaine / in suche licoure
Of which vertue / engendrid is the floure
When Zephirus / eke with his soote breath
Enspired hath / every holte and heath
The tendre croppes / and the yonge sonne
Hath in the Ram / half hise Course ironne
And smale foules / maken melodie
That slepen all nyght / with open eye
So pricketh hem nature / in hir courage
Then longen folke / to go on pilgrimage
And Palmers to seken / straunge strondes
To ferne seke halowes / couth in sondrie Londes
And specially / fro every shires ende
Of Englande / to Caunterbery they wende
The holie blisfull martire for to seke
That hem hath holpen / when they were seke
So It befell it that season vpon a daie
In Southwarke / at the Taberd as I laie
Redy to go wende / on my Pilgrymage
To Caunterbery with deuoute courage
That nyght was come into that ones hostelrie
Well nyne and twenty / in a company
Of sondrie diuers folke / by auenture ifall
In felyshippe / and Pilgrimes were they all
That toward Caunterbery woulde ride
The Chambers and stables wern wide
And well wexen they were wee eased / at the best
And shortly / when the sonne was at went to rest
So had I spoken / with hem euerchone
That I was / of her felishipp anone
And made forwarde / early for to rise
To take oure waie / there as I shall you devise
But Nethelesse / while I haue tyme and space
Or that I ferther / in this tale pase
Me thinke it / accordaunt it were to reason
To tell you all the Condicion
Of eche of hem / so as it semed me
And whiche they were / and of what degree
And eke in of what araie / that they were in
And at a knyght / then will I first begye
A knight there was and that a worthy man
That fro the tyme that he first gan
To riden out / he loued Cheua
Trouth / hono / fredome and curtesie
Full worthy was he in his lordes warre
And therto had he ridden / no man so farre
As well in Christendome / as in heathennes
And euer had honour / for his worthynesse
Alisaundir he was / when it was won
tyme / he had the bourde begon
Abouen all nations in Pruce
In Lettow had he ridden / and in Luce
Non Christian man / so ofte of his degree
A knighte there was and that a worthie man
That fro the tyme that he first began
To riden out / he loued Cheualrye
Trouth / Honour / Fredome / and Curtesy
Full worthy was he in his Lordes warre
And therto had he ridden no man so farre
As well in Christendome as in heathnes
And euer had honour / for his worthynes
At Alisaunder he was / when it was wonn
Full ofte tyme / he had the bourde begon
Abouen all nations in Pruce
In Lettow had he ridden been / and in Luce Ruce
No Christian man / so ofte of in his degree
In granade at the siege eke had he be
In algreth had he ryden and in belmarye
At Cartage was he and eke in satalye
Whenne they were wonne and in the grete see
At many a noble aryue had he be
At mortalle batailles had he be fiftene
And fought for oure feith at Tramyssene
In lystes thryes and hath slayne his foo
This ylke worthy knyght had be also
Somtyme wᵗith the lorde of Palathie
Ageyne anothir hethen man in Turkye
And eủer/remore he had a souereyne pryce
And though he was worthy he was wise
And of his port as meke as a mayde
He nevir yet vylaynes worde seyde
In alle his lyff to noman wight
He was a gentille ꝑper/parfitt knyght
For to telle you of his aray
His hors were good but he was not gay
Of fustian he wered a gipioun
Alle besmerede wᵗith his habergyoun
For he was late come fro his viage
And sent for to do his pilgremage
WIth hym there was a semely yonge Squyer
A louer and a luste bachyler
With lockes crulle as they were leyde in presse
Of twanty yere of Age he was I gesse
Of his stature he was of evene lenthe
And wondirly de lyuere and grete of strengthe
And he had be som tyme in chyualrye
In Flaundres in Artoyse and in Picardye
And borne hym welle as of alitle space
In hope to stonde in his ladyes grace
Enbrowede was he as hit were a mede
Alle fulle of freysh floures white and rede
Syngynge he was or floytynge alleday
He was as freyshe as ys the moneth of may
Short was his gowne wᵗith sleves longe and wide
Welle couth he sitt an hors and therto feire ryde
He couth songꝭes make and welle endyte
Iuste and daunce portray and eke wryte
So hote he louede that by nyghtertale
He slept nomore than a nyghtyngale
Curtese he was lowly and seruysable
He carf before his fader at the table
A yeman had he and seruantes nomoo
At that tyme for he lyst to ryde soo
And he was cled in cote and hood of grene
A sheffe of arowes bryght and shene
Vnder his belt he bare fulle thryftly
Welle coude he dresse his takille yomanly
His arowes drouped not wᵗith Fethers lowe
And in his honde he bare a myghty bowe
A not hede he had wᵗith abroun visage
Of wodemannes crafte coude he alle the vsage
Vppon his arme he bare a gay bracer
And by his side a swerde and a bokler
And on that othir side a gay daggare
Harneysede welle and sharpe as poynt of spere
A Cristofre on his breste fulle shene
An horne he bare a bawdryke grene
A Foster was he sothly as I gesse .
There was also anonne A Pryoures
That of hir smylynge was symple and koy
Here grettest oth was by seynt loy
And she was clepede Eglentyne
Fulle welle she songe seruyce dyuyne
Entoynede in hir voice fulle semely
And frenshe she spake fulle fotously
After the scole of Stratford at the bowe
For frenshe of Parys vas vnto hir vnknowe
At mete welle taught was she wᵗith alle
She let no morcelle from hir lyppes falle
Ne wete hir fyngers in hir sauce depe
Welle couth she cary a morcelle of mete
That no drope felle on hir breste
In curtesye was sett fulle mekely hir lest
Hir overlyppe weped she so clene
That in hir cuppe there was no ferthynge sene
Of grece whan she had dronke hir draught
Fulle semely after hir mete she raught
And sekyrly she was of grete desport
Of plesauᵃnce and amyable of port
And peynede hir to countirfete chiere
Of court to be statly of manere
And to be holde digne of reuerence
But for to speke of hir conscience
She was so charytable and so petous
She wolde wepe and she sawe amous
Kaught in a trappe yf hit were dede or blede
Of smale houndes had she that she fedde
With rost fleyshe mylke and wastelle brede
But sore wept she yf eny of hem were dede
If men smote hem with yerde smart
And alle was conscience and tendre hert
Fulle semely hir wymple pynchede was
Her nase tretise hir eyen grey as glas
Hir mouth smale and therto soft and rede
But sikyrly she had a feire forhede
Hit was almost a span brode I trow
For hardely she was not vndirgʳow
Fulle fetise was hir cloke as I was ware
Of smale coralle aboute hir arme she bare
A peire of bedes gauded alle with grene
And there on hynge a broche fulle shene
On the whiche that first was writte a croned .A.
And after that Amor vincit omnia
Anothir Nonne with hir ther was
Fulle feire of hewe and bright of face
That was hir chapleyn and prestes thre
Amonke there was feire for the maistre
Whiche afore that tyme had be
An out ryder he louede venore
A manly man to be an Abbot able
Fvll many adeynte hors had he in stable
And when he rode men myght hir brydille here
Gyngelynge and whistelynge in the wynde clere
And eke as lowde as deth a chapelle belle
There as the lorde was keper of the selle
The reule of Seynt Maure and of seynt benet
By cause he helde hit somwhat streyte
This ylke monke let olde thynges passe
And helde after the newe worlde the space
He yaf not of the text a pullet henne .
That seith that hunters be not holy men
Ne that a monke what that he is recheles
Is lyke to a Fyshe whanne it is waterles
This is to sey amonke out of a cloystre
But that text holde y not worth an oystre
And I sey that his opynyou was good
Whate shulde he stodye and make hym wode
Vppon a booke alwey in cloystre to powre
Or swynke with hondes and laboure
As Austyn did / but howe shalle the worlde be seruede
Let Austyn haue his swynke to hym reseruede
Therefore he was a pricasoure aryght
Grehoundes he had as mylke white
Of prykynge and of huntynge for the hare
Was alle his luste for nothyng wolde he spare
I sawe his sleues purfilde at the honde
With grice and that the fynest of a londe
And for to fasten his hode vndir the chynne
He had of golde wrought a coryous pynne
And eke his face as he had be anoynt
He was a lorde fatt and in good poynt
His eyen stepe and rollynge in his hede
That stemyd as a furneyes of lede
His botes sowpille his hors in grete a state
Nowe certeynly he was a feire prelate
He was not pale as a forpyned goste
A fat swan louede he best of eny roste
His palfrey was / as broun as a bery
He was a porke hogge for the maystry
A Frere there was awantou and a mery
A lymytoure and a fulle solemne man
In alle the orderys foure ys none that so wolle can
Somoche of dalyaunce and feire langage
He had made many a feire maryage
Of yonge womēm at his owne coste
Vntille his Order he was a noble poste
Fulle welle louede and fulle famyliar was he
Wᵗith Frankelens ovir alle in his con tre
And wᵗith worthy yomen of the toun
For he had power of confessioun
And plesaunt was his absolucoun
To them that had grete contricoun
And seyde hym selfe more than a curat
And of his ordre he was lycenciat
And an esy man to yeue penauᵃnce
There he wiste to haue a good pitauᵃnce
Vnto a poure ordre for to yeue
Whenne that aman is welle I shryve
Yf he yaue he durst make avauᵃnte
Yf that a man was repentauᵃnte
Many a man harde is of hert
He may not wepe though he sore smert
Therefore in stede of wepynge and pᵃyers
Men muste yeue siluere to the poure freres
Hit tipet was I fossede fulle of knyves
And wᵗith pynnes to yeue feire wyves /
And certeyn he had a mery note
Merely coude he synge and play at the rote
Of tithynges / he bare vtterly the pryce
Milke white he was as the floure delice
Therto stronge he was as a champioun
And knewe the tavarnes well in eủer/rey toun
And euery Osteler and tapstere
Better than a lazar or a beggestere
Forto vnto suche aman as he
Accordeth not as by his faculte
To haue of suche seke Lazars acqueyntance
Hit is not honest hit may not avaunce
For to dele with suche poraille
But wᵗith riche and sellers o vitaille
And ouer alle there as riches shuld aryse
Curteyse he was and lowe of seruyce
There was noman no where so vertouse
He was the best begger in his house
For though a wedowe had not a sho
So plesaunt was his in pryncipio
Yet wolde he haue a ferthynge or he went
His purchas was better than his rent
And barke he couth as hit were a whelpe
In louedays there couth he mykyl helpe
For there he was lyke a cloystrere
With a thredbare cope as a poure frere
But he was lyke a maister or a pope
Of dubbil . worstede was his semy cope
And rounde was as abelle out of presse
Somwhate he lysped for his wantounesse
To make his englysh swete vppon his tonge
And in his harpynge whenne he had I songe
His eyen twynkled in his hede aright
As done the sterres in the Frosty nyght
This worthy Frere was called hubbard
A Marchauᵃnt there was wᵗith a forked / berde
In motley on high on his hors he sate
Vppon his hed a flaundres bever hatte
Hit botes claspid feire and fetously
His resons he spake fulle solempnely
Shewynge alwey the encrece of his wynnynge
He wolde the see were kept for eny thynge
Betwyxt Middelburgh and Orewelle
Welle coude he in his eschanges selle
This worthy man his witt fulle well besette
There wist no wight that he was in dette
So estatly was he of gouernance
With his bargeyns and wᵗith his cheuesauᵃnce
For soth he was aworthy man with alle
ANd soth to sey I not howe men hy calle
A Clerke there was of Oxenford also
That vnto logik had longe I go
And lene was his hors as a rake
And he was not right fat I vndirtake
But loked holowe and therto sobirly
Fulle thredbare was his overest courtby
For he had gote hym yet no benefice
Ne was not wordly to haue an office
For hym was leuyr to haue at is beddes hede
Twanty bokes / I clad in white and rede .
Of Aristotle and of Philosophie .
Than robes riche or Fidle or sawtrye
But alle be that he was aphilosophre
Yet had he but litle golde in cofre
But al that he myght of his frendes haue helpe
On bokes and on lernynge he hit spent
And besely gan forthe soules pray
Of hem that yaue hym wherwith to scolaye
Of study toke he most cure and hede
Not o worde spake he more than nede
Short and quyk and high of sentence
Sownynge moral vertu was his prudence
And gladly wolde he lerne and gladly teche
And therwᵗith fulle soft was his speche .
A Sargeauᵃnte of lawe ware and wyse
Was there that oft had be at the ꝑper/par vyse
That was also riche of excellence
Discrete he was / and of grete reuerence
He semede suche his wordes were so wise
Iustice he was fulle ofte in assise
By patent and by pleyne Cōmmyssioun
For his science and his high renoun
Of fees and Robes had he many on
So grete a purchasoure was ther no where non
Alle was fee symple to hym in effect
His purchas myght not be to hym suspect
Nowhere so besy aman as he there was
And yet he semede besier than he was
In termes had he caas and domes alle
That from the tyme of kynge williām were falle .
Therto he coude endite and make athynge
There couth no wyght pynche at his wryttynge
And euery statute coud he pleyne by rote
He rode but homly in a medle cote
I girt with a syncte of silke wᵗith barres smale
Of his aray telle I no lenger tale
A Frankeleyn was in his compenye
White was his berde as the deysye
And of his complexciou was sanguyn
Welle louede he bythe morowe a cuppe of wyne
To lyue in delyte was euer his wone
For he was Epicuries owne sonne
That helde apynyou that pleyne delyte
Was verey felicite parfite .
An householder and that a grete was he
Seynt Iulyan he was in his countre
His brede his Ale was alwey after one
A better wynode man was nowher none
Withoute bake mete was he nevir in his hous
His Fyshe his Fleyshe and that so plentous
Hit showede in his hous of mete and drynke
Of alle deyntes that men couth thynke
After the sundry seasou of the yere
So chamgede he his mete and his soper
Fulle many a fatt partriche had he in mowe
And many a breme and luce in stewe
Wo was his cook but his sauce were
Poynant and sharpe and redy al his geere
His table dormaunt in his halle alwey
Was redy couerede alle the longe day
At sessions there was he lorde and sire
Fulle ofte tyme he was knyght of the shire
A lace and a Gipser of silke
Hynge at his girdille as white as morowe mylke
A shereue had he be and a coronoure
Was nowhere suche aworthy vauesoure
AN hadirdayssher ther was and a Carpenter
A Web a dyer and a tapiser
And they were clothed alle in o lyuere
Of a solempne and a grete fraternyte
Fulle freysh and newe her gere piked was
Here knyves chapid were not wᵗith bras
But alle wᵗith siluere wrought fulle clene ⁊and welle
Here girdelys and her powches euerydele
Welle semede eche of hem a feire Burgeys
To sitt in the yelde halle at the deys
Eueryche for the wisdome that he can
Was happely for to be an Aldirman
For cateille had they ynough and reste rent
And here wyves wold hit welle assent
And elles certeyne they were to blame
Hit is fulle feire to be called Madame
And go to vigilles alle before
And haue a mantelle rially I bore
A Cooke they had wᵗith hem forthe nones /
To boille the chekenes and the mary bones
And powder marchant tart and galyngale
Welle knowe he adraught of londou ale
He couth / roste / seth / boylle and frye
Make mortrewes and welle bake apye
But grete harme was it as it thought me
For on his chyn a Mormale had he
And blanke Manger made he with the best /
A Shipman was there that wonede fer beweste
For ought I wote he was of dertemoth
He rode vppon a rouncy as he couth
In a gowne foldynge to the kne
A dagger and a lace hangynge had he
Aboute his neck vndir his Arme a doun
The hote somer had made his hewe alle broun
And certeynly he was agood felowe
Fulle many adraught wyne he had drawe
Fro burdeux warde while the chapmām slepe
Of concience toke he no kepe
At fulle many a bataile in that londe
He faught and had the higher honde
But of his crafte to rekon welle his tide
His stremes . and his daungers hym beside
There was none suche from hul in to Cartage
For wyse he was though he were fulle of corage
Hardy he was and ware to vndirtake
With many a tempest his berde hath quake
He knewe alle the hauens that there were
From Englonde in to the Capfenestre
And euery cryke in brytayne and in spayne
His barge was called the Maudeleyne
WIth vs there was . a Doctour of phisik
In the worlde was there none hy lyk
To speke of Phisik and Surgerye
For he was grounded in Astronomye
He kept his pacient a grete dole
In hour be magik naturelle
Welle couth he of fortune the Accident /
Of his ymage for his pacyent /
He knewe the cause of euery maladye
W̉er/ree hit of colde / hete / moyst or drye
And were engendred of whate humour
He was a verey ꝑper/parfitt practesour
Tho cause he knew and of his harme the rote
Anone he yaue the sekeman hit bote
For redy alwey be his apotecaryes
To sende hym drugges and his lettewaryes
For eche of them made other for to wynne
Her frendshippe was not new to begynne
Fulle welle knew he the olde Esculapius
And Diascorid and eke platearyus
Olde Ypocras / haly and eke Galiene
Serapyou / Rasis / and eke Avicene
Auerrois / Damascene / and Constantyn
Bernard / Gatisden and Gilbertyn
Of his dyete mesurable was he
For it was of no suꝑper/parfluyte
But of grete noryshynge and digestible
His stody was but litle on the bible
In sangwen and in perce I clad wᵗith alle
Lynede wᵗith taffate and with sandalle
And litle he was of his dispence
He kept that he wan in the pestilence
For golde in Phisik is a cordialle
Therfore he louede golde in specialle .
A Good wiff ther was of biside bathe
And she was somdele deef and that was scathe
Of cloth makynge had she suche an haunt
She passede hem of ypre or of gaunt
In alle the Paryshe wyff was there non //
That to the Offrynge be fore hir shulde gone
And yf there certeyn wroth was she
Thanne was she out of alle charite
Hir kercheues fulle fyne were of grounde
I durst sey they weyede thre pounde
That on a sonday were on hir hede
Hir hosyn were of fyne scarlett rede
Fulle streyte y tyede and shoes fulle newe
Bolde was hir face feire and rede of hewe
She was a worthy womām al hir lyue
Housbandes at the churche had she fyue
Withouten othir compeny in youth
But herof nedeth not to speke as nowth
At Acres had she bene and at Iherusaleme
She had passede throwe many a stronge reme
At Rome she had bene and at Babyloyne
At seynt Iames in Galice and at Coleyne
She coude moche of wandrynge in the wey
Gap tothod was she sothly to sey
Vppon an Ambler fulle easely she sate
I wympled welle and on hir hede an hatte
As brode as it were a bokeler or a targe
A fote mantele aboute hir hippes large
And on hir heles a peire of spores sharpe
In feloshippe coude she laugh and carpe
Of remedyes of loue she coude ꝑper/par chauᵃnce
For of that art she coude the dauᵃnce
A Good man there was of Relygiou
And was a poure ꝑper/parson of a toun
But riche he was and holy of werke
He was also a lernede man a clerke
That cristes gospelles truly wolde preche
His paryshons deuotly wolde teche
Benygne he was and wonder diligent
And in aduersite fulle pacient
And suche he was / ꝓprouede oft sithes
Fulle loth were he to curse for his tithes
But rather wolde yeue out of doute
Vnto his pover paryshones aboute
Of his offrynge and his sustenauᵃnce
He coude in litle thynge haue suffisauᵃnce
Wyde was his paryshe and houses fer asondir
But he let not for reyne ne for thoundir
In siknesse nor in myscheff to visite
The ferrest in his parysh more and lite
Vppon his fete / and l in his honde a staff
This noble ensample vnto his sheepe he yaff
That first he wrote and aftirwarde taught
Out of the gospell the wordes he caught
And this figure he ekede therto
That if golde ruste what shuld Iren do
For aprest to be foul . in whom we trust
No wondir is a lewde man to ruste
And shame it is yf a prest take kepe
A slotty shepherde and a clene shepe
Wolle ought aprest ensample to yeve
Be his clennes / howe his shepe shuld lyve
Be sett not his benefice to hire
And let his shepe acombre in the myre
And ron to londou to seynt Poules /
And seke hym a chauntrie for soules
Other with a bretherede to be witholde
But dwelle at home and kepe his folde .
So that the wolfe ne had the maystrye
He was a shippard / and not a mercenarye
And though he holy were and vertous
He was not to a synful mām to despitous
But in his speche discrete and benygne
Ne of his techynge daungerous ne digne
To drawe folke to heuen with feirenesse .
Be good ensample this was his besynesse .
But it were eny ꝑper/parsone obstinat
Whedir he were of high or lowe estate
Hym wolde he snybbe sharply for the nonys /
A better prest I trowe nowhere none ys
He wayted aftir no pompe ne reuerence .
He had no spicede conscience

He taught but first he folowede hym selue .
Wth hym there was aplowmām was his brothir

A trew swynker and a good was he

God louede he best with alle his herte
At alle tymes they he gamede or smerte
And then his neighbore right as hym self
He wolde threysh and therto digge and delf
For cristes sake for euery poure wight
Withouten hire yf it lay in his myght
His tithes payde he both feire and welle
Of his propre swynke and his catelle
In a tabard he rode vppon a mere /
That he was ay before and in good state
Nowe is not that of god a feire grace

Of maistirs had he moo than thries ten

To make hym . leue be his owne goode
In honoure detles but he were wode
Othir lyve scarsly as hym lyst desire
And for to helpe alle the shire
In eny cause that myght falle or happe

His herys were be his eres / rounde I shore

Fulle longe was his legges and fulle lene .
Lyke a staff there nys no calfe y sene .
Welle coude he kepe a garner and a bynne
There was non Auditour coude of hy wynne
Welle wiste he . by the drought and by the reyne
The yeldynge of his sede and of his greyne
His lordes shepe his nete and his deirye
His swyns his hors his store and his pultrye
Was holy in this Ryves gouernynge
And by his couenant yaue the rekenynge .

A sompnore and A Pardener also

There was also a Reve and eke a Millere also
THe myller was a stout carle for the nones

At wrastlynge alwey he wolde alwey haue the ram

His nostrelles blake were and wide

He was a iangeler and a ioly hardeys

For to be wise in beynge of vitaille

Ther coude noman brynge hym in rerage
There nas bailly ne nonothir hyne

They were of hym adrad as of the deth
His wonynge was feir vppon an heth
With grene teeys shadowed was his place
He coude better than his lorde purchace .
Fulle riche he was astored preuely
His lorde he coude pleace discetly
To yeue ayen to hym of his owne good
And haue thanke and yet a cote and an hode
In youth . he had lerned a good mystere
He was a wel good wright a Carpentere
This Reue sate vppon awelgood stott
That was alle pomel grey and hight scott
A longe surcote of Perce vpon hy he had
And by his side he bare a rusty blad
Of Northfolke was this Reve of whiche I telle
Beside a tou men calle Baldilwelle .
Tucked he was as is afrere aboute
And euyr he rode the hynderest of the rowte /
A Sompnere wᵗith vs was in that place

For sausfleme he was wᵗith eyen narowe
Hote he was and lykerous / as a sparowe
With blake browes scalled and pilled berde
Of his visage children were a ferde
There nas quyksiluere litarge ne brymstone
Borace ceruce ne oyle of tartre none
Ne oynement that ychith or byte
That myght helpe his whelkes white
Ne of his knobbys syttynge in his chekes /
Wolle louede he Oynons garlek and lekes
And for to drynke rede wyne as red as blode
Than wolde he speke and cry as he were wode
And when he had welle dronke the wyne
Than wolde he speke no worde but latyne .
Fewe termes had he two or thre .
That he had lerned of som man of degre
No wondir is he herde it alle the day
And eke ye knowe welle that a iay
Can clepe watte as welle as the pope
But who coude hym in othir thyngꝭes grope
Than had he spent alle his Philosophie

He was a gentille harlott and a kynde
A better folowe shuld nomām fynde
He wolde suffre for a quart of wyne
A good felowe to haue his concubyne
A twelf moneth and excuse hym at the fulle
Fulle pⁱriuely a fynche eke coude he pulle
And yf he founde owher a good felowe
He wolde teche hym anone to haue awe
In suche caas / of the Archidekenes curs /
But yf mannes soule were in his purs /
For in hispurs he sholde punyshede be
Purs is the Archideknes helle seide he
But welle I wote he liede in dede
Of cursynge ought eche man to drede
For cursyng wolle sle right as soylynge saueth
And also ware hym of significauit
In daunger had he at his owne gise .
Alle the yonge girles of the dyocyse .
And knewe of her councelle and was of her rede
A garlonde he had set vppon his hede
Asgrete as hit were an Alestake
A bokeler had he made hym of a Cake
WIth hym there rode a gentil ꝑper/par donere

That streyght was come from the Pope of rome
Fulle lowde he songe com hedir leue grome
This sompnore bare to hym a stiff burdone
Was nouyr trompe of halfe so grete a sowne
This ꝑper/pardener had heere as yolowe as wexe
And smoth hit hynge as doth a stryke of flexe
Be hynde his lockes that he hadde
And there wᵗith his shuldrys / ouer spradde
But then hit lay by culpons one and one
And hode for colde wered he none
For it was trussede vp on his walet
Hym thought he rode on the newe get
Dissheuyld saue is cappe he rode albare
Suche glarynge eyen had he as hath an hare
His walet beforn hym had he in his lappe
A vernacle had he sowede vppon his cappe
Brett fulle of pardou come fro rome alhote
A voice he had as smale as hath a goote
No berde had he ne nevir shulde haue
Asmothe was it as it were newe shaue
I trowe he were a goldynge or A mare
But of his craft from Berwik vnto ware
Ne was there nowhere suche A pardenere
For in his male he had a pilowe beere .
Whiche that he seide was oure ladies veyle .
He seide he had a gobett of the seill

Vppon the see tille Ihus crist hym hent
He had a crosse of latou fulle of stones

But wᵗith this reliques when that he fonde
A poure ꝐPer/Parsone dwellynge vppon londe
Vppon a day he gate he gate hym more mone

And thus hath he feyned flatryes ⁊and Iapes /
He made the persou and the peple his apes /
But truly to telle at the laste
He was in churche a noble eccleciaste
Welle coude he rede a lessou or a story
But alderbest he songe an offretory
For welle he wiste whēm that songe was songe
He must pche and file awhile his tunge
To wynne siluere as he welle can
Therfore he songe the meryer than
NOwe haue I tolde you shortly in a clause
The state the aray the nombre ⁊and the cause
Whi that assembled / was this compenye
In Southwerke at this gentille hostelrye
That hight the Tabard faste by the belle
But nowe is tyme to you for to telle
Howe that we bare vs that ilke nyght
When that we were in the hostry alight
And after wolle I telle of oure viage
And alle the remenant of oure pilgrymage
But first I you pray of youre curtesye
That ye ne rekene not my vylonye
Thought that I pleynly speke in this matere .
To telle you here wordes and her chere
And though I speke her wordes propirly
For this ye knowe as welle as y
Who shalle a tale telle after a man
He muste reherce as nere as he can
Euery worde yf hit be in his charge
Al speke he so rudely and so large .
Or elles he muste telle his tale vntrewe
Or sey thynges or feyne wordes newe
He may not spare al though he were his brothir
He mote sey as welle o worde as a nothir
Criste spake hym selfe brode in holy wryt
And welle ye wote no vilany is it
Eke Plato seith who so can it rede
The worde muste be cosyn to the dede
Also I pray you for yeue it me
Al though I sett not folke in her degre
Here in this tales . as they shuld stonde
My witt is short ye may welle vndirstonde
GRete chere made oure ost to vs eủer/reychon
And to soper sett vs anon
He seruede vs with vitaille at the beste
Stronge was the wyne and drynke vs liste
A semely man oure host was with alle
For to be a marchal in a lordes halle
A large man he was with eyen stepe
A feirerburges is there none in I chepe
Bolde of his speche and welle was I taught
And of manhode lacked he right noght
Eke therto was he right a mery man
And after soper to pley he began
And spake of mirth a monge othir thynges
When that had made oure rekenynges
He seyde thus nowe lordynges tendirly
Ye be to me welcome hertely
For by my trouth yf I shalle not ly
I sawe not this yere so mery a compeny
At ones / in this herborowe as nowe
Feyne wolde I do you myrth yf I wist howe
And of my mirth I am right now be thought
To do you ease and it shalle coste you noght
Ye go to Caunterbury god you spede
The blessede martir quytt youre mede
And welle ye wote as ye goo by the weye
Ye shappen you to talke and to play
For truly comfort ne myrth is none
To ryde by the wey dom as a stone
And therfore wolle I make you disport
As I seyde erst and do you comfort
And yf it liketh you alle be one assent
For to stonde at my Iugement
And for to werke as I shalle you sey
To morowe whan ye ryde on the wey
Nowe by my fadir soule that is dede
But ye be mery I . shalle you yeve my hede
Holde vp youre honde wᵗithoute more speche
Oure councelle shalnot longe be to seche
Vs thought not worth to make vs wyse
And graunted hym without more avise
And bade hym sey his verdit as hym list
Lordynges quod he nowe herkeneth for the best
But take it not I pray you in dysdeyne
This is the poynt to speke it short and pleyne
That eche of you to short with youre wey
In this viage shalle telle tales twey
To Caunterbury warde I mene it so .

And whiche of you bereth hym best of alle

And for to make you the more mery

And who that wille my iugement with sey

This thynge was graunted and othes swore

And that he wolde be oure gouernoure
And of oure tales / Iuge and reportoure
And sett a sopere at a certeyne pryce

High and lowe and alle be one assent
We be accordede to the Iugement

Lett se nowe who shalle telle the first tale

NOwe drawe cutt / or that ye ferthir twynne

Anone to withdrawe eủer/rey wight began

Were it be aventure fortune or caas

Nowe let vs ryde and herken whate I sey

(base) Ther as he hadde / hise amorouse desires
(base) His compleinte / and for loue his hote fyres
(base) He wolde make a fyr / in which the office
(base) Funeral / he myghte al acomplice
(base) And leet anoon comaunde / to hakke and hewe
(base) The okes olde / and leyen hem on a rewe
(base) In colpons / wel arrayed for to brenne
(base) Hise officers / with swifte feet they renne
(base) And ryde anoon / at his comandement

div.l: (base) And after this / Theseus hath ysent
(base) After a Beere / and it al ouerspradde
(base) With clooth of gold / the richeste / that he hadde
(base) And of the same suyte / he cladde Arcite
(base) Vpon his handes / his gloues white
(base) Eek on his heed / a coroune of laurer greene
(base) And in his hand / a swerd ful bright and keene
(base) He leyde hym bare the visage / on the beere
(base) Ther with he weep / that pitee was to heere
(base) And for the peple / sholde seen hym alle
(base) Whan it was day / he broghte hym to the halle
(base) That roreth / of the cryyng and the sown
(base) Tho cam / this woful Theban Palamoun
(base) With flotry berd / and ruggy asshy heerys
(base) In clothes blake / ydropped al with teerys
(base) And passyng othere / of wepyng Emelye
(base) The rufulleste / of al the compaignye
(base) In as muche / as the seruyce sholde be
(base) The moore noble / and ryche in his degree
(base) Duc Theseus / leet forth thre steedes brynge
(base) ¶ Duke theseus anon with oute lette
(base) Thre stedis white hath comaundid sette
(base) Vpon the whiche stedes trapped welle
(base) With cloth of golde ouer maile of stel
(base) That trapped weren in steel al gliterynge
(base) And couered with the armes / of daun Arcite
(base) Vpon thise steedes / grete and whyte
(base) Ther seten folk / of which oon baar his sheeld
(base) Another his spere / vpon his hondes heeld
(base) The thridde bar with hym / his bowe Turkeys
(base) Of brend gold / was the caas / and eek the harneys
(base) And ryden forth a paas / with sorweful cheere
(base) Toward the groue / as ye shul after heere
(base) The nobleste of the Grekys / that ther were
(base) Vpon hir shuldres / carieden the beere
(base) With slak paas / and eyen rede and weete
(base) Thurgh out the Citee / by the maister streete

div.l: (base) That sprad was al with blak and wonder hye
(base) Right of the same / is the strete ywrye
(base) Vpon the right hand / wente olde Egeus
(base) And on that oother syde / duc Theseus
(base) With vessels in hir hand / of gold ful fyn
(base) Al ful of hony / melk / and blood and wyn
(base) Eek Palamon / with ful greet compaignye
(base) And after that / cam woful Emelye
(base) With fyr in hande / as was that tyme the gyse
(base) To do the office / of funeral seruyse
(base) ¶ Heigh labour / and greet apparaillynge
(base) Was at the seruyce / and the fyr makynge
(base) That with his grene top / the heuene raughte
(base) And twenty fadme of brede / the armes straughte
(base) This is to seyn / the bowes / were so brode
(base) Of stree first ther was leyd many a lode
(base) But how the fyr was maked vpon highte
(base) Ne eek the names / how the trees highte
(base) As ook / Fyrre / Birch / Asp / Alder / holm / popler
(base) Wylow / Elm / Plane / Assh / Box / Chestayn / lynde / laurer
(base) Wilow / elme / plane hasil and whipultre
(base) Mapul / Thorn / Beech / hasyl / Ew / whippultree
(base) Mapil thorn / bech / aspe / box chesteyn lynd / laurer
(base) How they were feld / shal nat been told for me
(base) Ne how the goddes / ronnen vp and doun
(base) Desherited / of hir habitacioun
(base) In which they woneden / in reste and pees
(base) Nymphes / Fawnes / and Amadrides
(base) Ne how the beestes / and the bryddes alle
(base) Fledden / for fered / whan the wode was falle
(base) Ne how the ground / agast was of the lyght
(base) That was nat wont to seen the sonne bright

div.l: (base) Ne how the fyr / was couched first with stree
(base) And thanne with drye stikkes / clouen a three
(base) And thanne with grene wode / and spicerye
(base) And thanne with clooth of gold / and with perrye
(base) And thanne with cloth of golde and with perie
(base) And gerlandes hangynge / ful of many a flour
(base) The Mirre / thencens / withal so greet sauour
(base) Ne how Arcite / lay among al this
(base) Ne what richesse / aboute the body is
(base) Ne how that Emelye / as was the gyse
(base) Putte in the fyr / of funeral seruyse
(base) Ne how she swowned / whan men made the fyr
(base) Ne what she spak ne what was hir desir
(base) Ne what Iuels / men in the fyr caste
(base) Whan that the fyr was greet and brente faste
(base) Ne how somme caste hir sheeld / and somme hir spere
(base) And of hir vestimentz / whiche that they were
(base) And coppes fulle of Milk and wyn and blood
(base) In to the fyr / that brente as it were wood
(base) Ne how the Grekys / with An huge route
(base) Thries ryden / al the fyr aboute
(base) Vpon the left hand / with a loud shoutynge
(base) And thries / with hir speres claterynge
(base) And thryes wᵗith here sperys claterynge
(base) And thries / how the ladyes gonne crye
(base) And how that lad / was homward Emelye
(base) Ne how Arcite / is brent to Asshen colde
(base) Ne how that lychwake / was yholde
(base) Al thilke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
(base) The wake pleyes / ne kepe I noght to seye
(base) Who wrastleth best naked / with oille enoynt
(base) Ne who that baar hym best in no disioynt
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) I wol nat tellen al / how they goon
(base) Hoom til Atthenes / whan the pleye is doon
(base) But shortly to the poynt than wol I wende
(base) And maken / of my longe tale an ende
(base) ¶ By proces / and by lengthe of certeyn yerys
(base) Al stynt is / the moornynge and the terys
(base) Of Grekys / by oon general assent
(base) Thanne semed me / ther was a parlement
(base) At Atthenes / vpon a certeyn point and caas
(base) Among the whiche pointes / yspoken was
(base) To haue / with certeyn contrees alliance
(base) And haue fully / of Thebans obeisance
(base) For which / this noble Theseus anon
(base) Leet senden / after gentil Palamon
(base) Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
(base) But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
(base) He cam at his comandement / in hye
(base) Tho sente Theseus / for Emelye
(base) ¶ Whan they were set and hust was al the place
(base) And Theseus / abiden hath a space
(base) Er any word / cam from his wise brest /
(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
(base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
(base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
(base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence
(base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
(base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool
(base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
(base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue
(base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due
(base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
(base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
Here endeth the knyghtes tale / / And begynneth the Milleris Prologe
Whan that the knyght had thus his tale tolde
In alle the compeny nas ther yonge ne olde
That he ne seide it was a noble story
And worthy to be drawe in memory
And namly the gentilis euerychone
Our hoste lowgh an swore so mot I gone
Thus vnboklede wel is the male
Let se nowe who shalle telle anothir tale
For truly the game is welle begonne .
Nowe telle ye sir monke yf that ye conne
Somwhate to quytt wᵗith the knyghtes tale
The mylwarde that for dronken was and pale
So that vnnethes vppon his hors he sate
He nolde avale nothir hode ne hat
Ne abide nomām for his curtesye
But in Pilates voice he gan crye
And swore be Armys blode and bonys
I canne anoble tale for the nonys
The which I wille nowe quyt the knyghtꝭes tale
Oure oste sawe that he was dronken of ale
And seide abide Robyn leue brothir
Som bettir mām shalle telle first anothir
Abide let vs werke thriftly
Be cockes soule quod he that nylnot I
For I wille speke or elles go my wey
Oure oste answerd tel on adevilwey
Thou art a fole thy witt is oủer/recome
Nowe herkeneth quodthe Myller alle ⁊and some
But first I make a protestaciou
That I am drongke I knowe be my soun
And therfore yf I aught mysse speke or sey
Wite it the ale of Southwerke I you pᵃy
For I wolle telle a legende and a lyf
Both of a Carpenter and of his wiff
Howe that the Clerke hath set the wrightꝭes cappe
The Reve answered and seide stynt thy clappe
Let be thy lewede dronken harlatrye
Hit is synne and eke grete folye
To appeire eny man or hym defame .
And eke brynge wyves in suche a Nane
Thou maiste ynough of othir thyngꝭes sayn
The dronken mylward spake fulle sone ageyn
And seide leue brothir Oswalde
Who hath no wife he is no cokolde
But I sey not therfore that thou art on
There beth good wyves many on
Why art thou angry wᵗith my tale nowe
I haue awiff parde as welle as thowe
Yet nold I not for the oxen in my plowe
Take vppon me more than yowe
And deme of my selfe that I were one
I wille beleue that I am none .
An housband shuld not be inquysitiff
Of goddes pryuetees ne of his wiff
So he may fynde goddes foyson there
Of the remenᵃnt nedeth not to enquere
Whate shuld I more sey but this myllere
He nold his worde for nomām forbere
But tolde his cherles tale in his manere
Me ouer thynketh that I shalle reherse it here
And therfore euery gentil wight I pᵃy
Demeth not for goddes loue that I sey
Not for eville entent but that I muste reherce
Here talys al be they better or werce
Or elles falsen som of my matore
And therfore who lo lysteth not to here
Turne ovir the lefe and chese anothir tale
For he shal fynde ynowe both grete and smale
Of hystoryalle thynge that toucheth gentilnes
And eke moralite and holynes
Blameth not me yf that ye chese amys
The Miller is a churle ye knowe welle this
So is the Reve and eke othir moo
And harlottrye they told both twoo
Aviseth you and put me out of blame
And eke mēm shul not make ernest of game .
Whilome there was dwellynge in Oxenforde
A riche chuf that gestis had to borde
And of his crafte he was a Carpenter
Withym there was dwellynge a poure scoler
Had lerned art but alle his fantasye
Was turnyd for to lerne astrologie
And coude a certen of conclusions
To demyn by interrogacions
If that mēm axed hym certeyn hourys
Whedir they shuld haue drought or shorys
Or yf that mām axed hym whate shuld be falle
Of euery thynge I may not rekene alle
This clerke was cleped hende Nicholas
Of derne loue he coude and of solas
And therto he was sly and fulle pryue
And like a mayden meke for to se
A chambir had he in that hostelrye
Alone withouten eny compenye
Fulle fetously dight wᵗith herbes sote
And he hym selfe was swete as is the rote
Of licorice or of eny Cetewale
His Almageste his bokes grete and smale
His astrologie / longynge for his art /
His awgrym stones lay feire apart
On sheluys couched at his beddes hede
His presse y couered wᵗith a faldynge rede
And al aboue there lay agay sawtre
On whiche he made a nyghtis melodye
So swete that alle the chambir ronge
And Angelus ad virginēm he songe .
And aftir that he songe the kynges note
Ful often blissed was his mery throte
And thus this swete clerke his tyme spent
Aftir his spendynge and his rent
This Carpenter had wedded anewe wiff
Whiche that he louede more thām his lyff
Of xxviij yere she was of age .
Ielouys he was and holde hir narowe in cage
For she was wilde and yonge and he was olde
And demed hym selfe lyk to be a Cokewolde
He knewe not Caton . for his wit was rude
That biddeth amām wed his symylitude
Mon shuld wed aftir her estate .
For youth and old ben ofte at debate
But sithyn he was fallen in the snare
He muste endure as othir folkes his care
As eny wesil her body gent was and smale
And therto her kirtil pynched with alle
A synct she wered y barred alle of silke
A barmecloth as white as morowe mylke
Vppon hir lendys wᵗith ful many a gore
White was hir smok and browdrid alle before
And eke behynde on hir coler aboute .
Of cole blake sik withyn and without
The tapettis of hir white voluper
Were of the same sewte of the coler
Her filet blr brode of sik and set fulle hye
And sickyrly she had a licorowes eye
Fulle smale I pullid were her browes two
And they were bent and blake as eny slo
She was more blysful on to se
Than is the I newepere genet tre
And softer than is the wolle of the de wedir
And by hir girdille hangeth a purs of ledir
Tarselid wᵗith grene and ꝑper/parled with laton
And in alle this world to seke vp and don
There is nomām so wise that coude thenche
So gay a pupelot or so praty awenche
Fulle brighter was she shynynge of her hue
Than in the toure the noble forged newe
But of hir songe sho was so lowde and yern
As eny swalowe sittynge on the bern
Therto she coude skyppe and make game
As eny kid or Calf folowynge his dame
Her mouth was swete as braket or methe
Or hord of appullis leide on hey or hethe
Wynsynge she was as is a ioly colt
Longe as a maste and vpright as a bolt
A broche br she bare vppon hir lowe coler
As brode as ys the boos of a bokeler
Hir shoue were lacede on hir legges hye
She was a prymerolle a piggys nye
For eny lorde to liggen in his bed
Or yet for eny good yomām to wed
Nowe sire and eft sire sobe felle the caas
That on a day this hende Nicholas
Fil wᵗith this yonge wiff to rage and to playe
Whiles that hir housband was at Osneye
As clerkes be fulle subtille and fulle queynt
And pryuely he caught hir by the queynt
And seide y wille but yf I haue my wille
For dern loue of the lemmām I spille .
And helde hir harde by the shanke bones
And seyde lemmām loue me at ones
Or I wille dye al so god me saue .
And she spronge as a colt in the traue
And with hir hed she wryeth fast awey
She seyde I wilnot . kysse the be my fey
Why let be quoth she let be Nicholas
Or elles I wille cry out and allas
Do wey yoᵘur hondes for youre curtesye
This Nicholas gan mercy for to crye
And spake so feire and proffred hir so faste
That she her loue graunted hy at the laste
And swere her Oth be seynt thomas of kent
That she wold be at his cōmmaundement
Whan that she may her leyser welle aspye
Myn housband is so fulle of iososye
But ye be ware welle and be pryue
I wote right welle I am but ded quod she
Ye muste be ful derne as in this caas
Nay therof care I not quod Nicholas
A Clerke had lewdly be set his while
But yf he coude a Carpenter begile
And thus they bene accorded and I sworn
To waite a tyme as I haue tolde beforne
Whan Nicholas had do thus euerydele .
And thacked aboute the lendes welle .
He kyste hir swete and to his sawtrye
And pleid fast and made melodye
Than fil it thus that to the paryshe churche .
Cristes owne werkes for to werche .
This good wiff went on an haly day
Hir forhede shone as bright as eny day
So was it weyshe whan she let hir werke
Nowe was there of that churche a parysh clerke
Cristes owne workes for to werche
This good wiff went on an haly daye
The whiche was cleped Absolon .
Crulled was his here as the gold it shone
And strouted as a fan large and brode
Fulle streight and evene lay his ioly shode
His rode was rede his eyen grey as goos
With poules wyndowes corven in his shoes
In hases red he went fulle fetously
In a kyrtille or alitle waget /
Fulle feire and wolle be the poyntes set
And there vppou he had agay surples
As white as blossome on the rys
A mery childe he was so god me saue
Welle coude he let blode and eke shaue
And make a Chartoure of londe and acquitance
In twanty maners coude he trippe and daunce
Aftir the scole of Oxenford / tho .
And with his hondes caste to and fro /
And play songes with a smale ribible
Therto he songe tyme a lowde quynyble
And wolle coude he play on his getarne
In alle the toun nas brewe hous ne tavarne
That he ne visited it with his salace
There as eny gailard tapster was
But soth to sey he was somdele Skweymous
Of fartynge and of speche daungerous
This absolon that ioly was and gaye
Goth wᵗith a sensoure on the holy daye
Sensynge wyves of the parysh faste
And many a louely loke on hem he caste
And namly on this Carpynters wiff
To loke on hir hym thought a mery lyff
She was so propre swete and eke licorous
I dar welle sey yf she had be a mows
And he a catt he wold hir hente anone
This parish clerke this ioly absolone
Hath in his hert suche aloue longynge
That of no wyff toke he none offrynge
For curtesye he seyde he wold none .
The mone whan hit was nyght bright shone
And absalon his gittarne had I take
For ꝑper/paramours he thought for to wake .
And forth he goth iolyf and amorous
Tille he cam to the Carpynters hous
Alitle aftir cockes had I crowe .
And dressed hym vppe be the shot wyndowe
That was opyn the Carpynters walle .
He syngeth in his voise . gentille and smalle .
Nowe dere lady yf thy wille be
I pray you that ye wille thynke on me
Fulle welle accordynge to his giternynge
This Carpynter herde hym synge
And spake vnto his wiff and seid anone
Whate Alison herist thou not Absolone
That chaunteth thus vndir our bowris wal .
And she answered her housband therwth al
Yes god wote Iohn I here hit euery dele
This passeth forth what wol ye bet thām wele .
From day to day this ioly Absolon
So woweth hir that he is wo begon
He waketh alle the nyght and al the day
He kembeth his lockes brode and maketh hym gay
He woweth hir be menes of brocage
And swore he wolde be hir owne page .
He syngeth brokynge as a nyghtyngale
He sent aftir pyment methe and spiced ale
And wafris pypynge hote out of the glede
And for she was of toun he profred hir mede
For som folke wolle loue womēm for riches
And som for strokes and som for iolynes
Som tyme he sheweth his lustynes ⁊and maistrie
He pleyeth herodes vpon a scaffold hye
But whate availleth hym as in this caas
She loued so this hende Nicholas
That Absolon may blowe the buckes horn
He ne had for his laboᵘur but a scorn
And thus she maketh Absolon her Ape
And alle his ernest turneth to a Iape .
Fulle soth is this proverbe / hit is no lye
Men sey alwey the nyght is slye
Maketh oftymes leef for to leth
For though that Absolon were wode or wroth
Bycause that he fer was from hir sight
This nyght Nicholas stode in his lyght
Nowe bere the welle nowe hende Nicholas
For Absoloun may waile and synge alas
And so be felle that on a satirday
This carpenter was gon to Osney
And eke hende Nicholas and Alison
Accorded be fully to this conclucion
That Nicholas shal shapēm hym a wile
This sely ielous housband to begile
And yf so be the game went aright
She shuld slepe in his armes alnyght
For this was her desire and his also
And right anone wᵗith out wordes mo
This Nicholas no lenger wold tary
But doth ful softe in to his chambir cary
Both mete and drynke for a day or twey
And to her housband bad hir for to sey
Yf that he axed aftir Nicholas
She shuld sey she nyst where he was
Of that day she sawe hym not wᵗith ye
She troueth that he is in som maladye
For that no cry her mayde myght hy calle
He nolde answere for no thynge myght falle
This passeth forth al that satirday
That Nicholas stille in his chambir lay
And ete or slept or did whate hym lyst
Tille sonday that the sonne goth to rest
This sely Carpenter hath grete mervaille
Of Nicholas or whate hym myght eille
And seid I am adoute be seynt thomas
Hit stondeth not aright wᵗith Nicholas
God shild that he diede sodenly
This world is nowe fulle tikil sikirly
I sawe a corps to day bore to churche
That nowe a monday laste I sawe hy wirche .
Go vp quod he vnto his knaue anone .
Clepe at the dore or knock wᵗith a stone .
Loke howe it is and telle me boldly
This knaue goth hym vppe ful sturdely
And at the Chambir dore while that he stode
He cryed and knocked as he were wode .
Whate how whate doi you maister Nicholay
Howe may slepen al the longe day
But alle for nought he herde not a worde
An hole fulle lowe he fonde vpou a borde
There as the catt was wont yn for to crepe
And at the hole he loked yn fulle depe
Tille at the laste he had of hym a sight
This Nicholas lay gapynge evir vpright
As he had loked on the newe mone .
A done he goth and telleth his maister sone
In what array he sawe this ilke man
This Carpynter to blysse hym be gan
And seide helpe vs seynt frideswide
Amām wote litle what hym shalle be tyde
This mām is fallen wᵗith his Astronomye
In some woodnes or in som Agonye .
I thought ay wel hough hit shuld be .
Men shuld not knowe of goddes pryuete
I blessed be alwey alewde man
That noght but only his belyue can .
So ferde anothir clerke wᵗith astronomye
He walked in the foldes for prye
Vppon the sterres whate there shuld befalle
Tille he was in a marle pitt I falle .
He sawe not that but yet be seynt thomas
Me reweth sore of hende Nicholas
He shalbe rated of his studynge .
If that I may be Ihu heuenkynge
Gete me a staff that I may vndirspore
While that thou robyn hevyst of the dore .
He shal out of his studynge as I gesse .
And to the chambir dore he gan hym dresse
His knaue was a stronge chorle for the nonys
And by haspe he haf it vppe at onys
In to the foor . the dore fille anon
This Nicholas sat as stille as eny ston
And euyr gaped vpward in the eyr
This Carpynter wende that he had be in despeir
And hent hym by the shuldirs myghtely
And shake hym harde and cryed spetously
Whate Nicholay what howe loke a doun
Awake and thynke on cristes passioun
I crouche the from elves and fro wightes
Therwith the nyghtspel seyde he and rightis
On foure halvis on the hous aboute
And on the threshold and on the dore wᵗithout
Ihu criste and seynt Benedight
Blysse this house from eủer/rey wicked wight
From nyghtes werry the wight pr nr
Where wonnest thow seynt Petris sustir
And at the laste this hende Nicholas
Gan for to sigh sore and seide Allas
Shalle alle the world be lost eft sones nowe
This Carpent̉er/re answered whate say thowe nowe
Whate thynke on god as we do mēm that swynke
This Nicholas answered fett me drynke
And aftir wille I speke in to the pryuete
Of certeyn thynges that touchen me ⁊and the
I wille it telle the and non othir mām certeyn
This Carpent̉er/re goth and cōmmeth ageyn
And brought of myghty ale alarge quarte
And when eche of hem had dronke his part
This Nicholas his dore fast shett
And doun the Carpent̉er/re be hym he sett
He seide Iohn myn hoste leue and dere
Thou shalt vppou thy trouth swere me here
That to no wight thou shalt this councelle wrey
For it is cristes councelle that I sey
And yf thou telle it mām thou art forlore
For this vengeance thou shalt haue therfore
That yf thou wrey me thou shalt be woode
Nay criste forbede it for his verey blode
Quod tho this sely mām I am no blabbe .
Ne though I sey I am not leef to gabbe
Sey whate thou wilt I shalle it nevir telle
To child ne wife be hym that harowed helle
Nowe Iohn quod Nicholas I wilnot lye /
I haue founde hit in myn Astrologie
As I haue loked in the mone bright
That now amonday next at quarte nyght
Salle falle arayn and that so wild ⁊and wode
That halfe so grete was nevir noyes flode
This wolde he seide in lesse than in an houre
Shalle albe dreynt so hidous ys the shoure
Thus shalle man kynde drenche and lese her lyf
This Carpenter answered allas my wif
And shalle shedrenche allas my Alysoun
For sorowe of this he fille almost doun
And seyde is there no remedy in this caas
Yes for god quod hende Nicholas
Yf thou wilt wirke after lore ⁊and rede
Thou maist not werke aftir thyn owne hede
For this seith Salamōm that was ful trewe
Worke al by councelle and thou shalt not rewe
And yf thou wirke wilt be good councelle
I vndirtake withouten mast or saille
Yet shalle I saue hir and the and me
Haste thou not herde howe saued was Noe
Whan that our lorde had warned hy beforne
That alle the world wᵗith watir shuld be lorne
Ye quod this Carpynt̉er/re ful yore agoo
Hasto thou not herde quod Nicholas alsoo
The sorowe of Noe wᵗith his fl felawshippe
Or that he myght gete his wiff to shippe
Hym had leuyr I dar welle vndirtake
At that tyme than alle his wetheris blake
That she had had a ship he selfe alone
And ther fore wotist thou whate is best to done .
This asketh haste and of an hasty thynge
May mēm not preche ne make tarynge
Anone go gete vs faste into this yn
A knedynge trough or elles a kemelyn
For eche of vs but loke that they be lage
In whiche we may swymme as in a barge
And haue thereyn vitaille sufficiauᵃnt
But for o day fy on the remenauᵃnt
The watir shalle a slake and goo awey
Aboute pⁱrime vppon the next day
But robyn may not witt of this thy knaue
Ne eke thy mayden gille I may not saue
Axe not why for thowe thou aske me
I wilnot telle goddes pryuete
Hit sufficeth the but yf thy witt be mad
To haue as grete a grace as Noe had
Thy wiff shalle I wel saue out of doute
Go nowe thy wey and spede the here aboute
But whan thou haste for the and her ⁊and me
Y goten this knedynge tubbes thre .
Then shalt thou honge hem in the roof ful hye
That nomām of oure pⁱriuete aspye
And when thou thus hast done as I haue seyde
And haste our vitaille feire in hem y leide
And eke an axe to smytte the corde a twoo
Whan that the watir cōmmeth that we may goo
And breke an hole an high vppōm the gabil .
In to the gardeyn ward ovir the stabil
That we may frely passe forth oure wey
Whan that the grete shoure is passed a wey
Than shulle we smymyn as merely I vndirtake
As doth the white doke aftir the drake .
Than wille I clepe you howe Alyson howe Iohne
Be mery for the flode wille passe anone
And thou wilt sey haile maistir Nicholay
Good morowe I se the welle for it is day
And than shalle we be lordes alle oure lyf
Of alle the world as Noe and his wiff
But of o thynge I warne the ful right
Be wel avised on that ilke nyght
Whan he entred in to the ship borde
That none of vs speke no worde
Ne clepe no cry but be in his pᵃyer
For it is goddes owne heste dere
Thy wif and thou must hange fer a twyn
For that betwyx you there be no syn
Nomore in lokynge than there shalle in dede
This ordenance is do O god the spede
To morowe at nyght when folke be alle a slepe
In to oure knedynge tubbes wol we crepe
And sitten there abidynge goddes grace
To make of this no lenger sermonynge
Men sey thus send the wise and sey nothynge
Thou art so wise it nedeth the not to teche
God saue oure lyff and I the beteche
This sely carpent̉er/re goth forth his wey
And to noman wold he it bewrey
But to his wiff he tolde his pryuete
And she was ware and knewe it bet than he
Whate alle this queynt cast was for to sey
But natheles she ferde as she wold dey
And seyde allas go forth thy wey anone
Helpe vs to scape or we be dede echone
I am thy tru wedded wiff
Go dere spouce and holpe to saue oure lyff
Lo whiche a grete thynge is affecciou
Men may dye alday of ymagynacou
So depe may impressiou be take
This sely Carpent̉er/re begynneth to quake
Hym thynketh verely that he may se
Noes flode come walowynge as the se
To drenchen alison his hony dere
He wepeth . wailleth and maketh sory chere
He sighed with many a sory swough
He goth and geteth hym a knedynge trough
And aftir that a tub and a kemelyn
And pryuely he sent hem in to his yn
And henge hem in the rof in pⁱriuete .
With his owne honde he mad laddirs thre
To clymben be the rongis and the stalkes
In to the towbes / hangynge in the balkes
And hem vitailled both trough and tub
With brede and chese ⁊and good ale in a Iub .
Suffisynge right Inough as for a day
But or that he had made alle that aray
He sent his knaue and eke his wenche also
Vppou his erant to londou forto goo
And on the sondey whan hit drewe to nyght
He shitt his dore withoutēm candille light
And dressed allthynge as hit shuld be
And shortly vp they clymben alle thre
They sittyn stille welle a furlond weye
Nowe Pater nr clum seide Nicholaye
And clum seide Iohn and clum seyde alysou
This Carpynter seide his deuociou
And stille he sitteth and biddeth his pᵃyer .
A waytynge on the rayne yf he hit here . //
The dede slepe for very werynesse .
Fille on this Carpenter right as I gesse
A boute Curfu tyme or litle more .
For trauaille of his goste he groneth sore
And efte he roteth for his hede mys lay
Done of the laddir stalketh Nicholay
And alsoun fullesofte doun she spedde
Withoutēm wordes mo they goo to bedde .
Eche gan othir in Armys plye
There was the reuel and the melodye
And thus lieth Alison and Nichalas
In besynes of myrth and solas
Tille that the belle of laudes gan to rynge
And Frerys in the chauncel gan to synge
This parysh clerke this absolon
That is for loue alwey so wo begon
Vppon the monday was at Osneye
With a compeny hym to disport and pleye
And asked vppou a caas a cloysterer
Fulle pⁱriuely aftir Iohn the Carpynter
And he drewe hym a part out of the churche
And seyde I not I sawe hym here not wirche
Sir satirday I trowe that he be went
For tymbir that oure Abbot hath hym sent
For he is wont for tymbir for to go
And dwelle at graunge a day or two
Or elles he is at his hous certeyn
Where that he be I can not sothly sayn
This Absolon ful ioly was and light
And thought now is tyme to wake alnyght
For sickirly y sawe hym not sterynge
Aboute his dore syn day gan to sprynge . / /
So mote I thryue y shal or cokkes crowe
Pryuely knocke at his wyndowe
That stont fulle lowe vppōm his bowrys wal
To Alison nowe wolle I tellen al .
My loue longynge fo yet I shalnot mys
That at the leste wey I shalle hir kys
Som maner comfort shalle I haue ꝑper/parfay
My mouth hath ycched alle this longe day
That is a signe of kyssynge at the leste
Alnyght I met eke that I was at a feste
Therefore I wolle go slepe an houre or twey
And al the nyght than wolle I wake ⁊and pley
Whan that the first cock hath crowe anone
Vp riseth this ioly louer Absone .
And hym araieth gay at poynt deuyse
But firste he sheweth greynes and licoryse
To smellen swete or he had kempt his heere
Vndir his toīmge a trewe loue he beere
For therby wende to haue be gracious
He rometh to the Carpynters hous
And stil he stont vndir the shot wyndowe
Vnto hir breste it raught hit was so lowe
And softe he knocketh wᵗith a semysoun
Whate do ye honycombe swete alson
My feire bred my swete Synamome
A waketh lemmām com and speke to me
Fulle litle thynke ye vppou my woo
That for youre loue I swete there I goo
No wondir is though I swelte and swete
I morne as doth a lambe aftir the tete
I wys lemmām I haue suche loue longynge / /
That like a turtil trewe ys my mornynge
I may not ete nomore than a mayde
Go fro the wyndowe Iack foole she seyde
As helpe me god it wol not be combame
I loue anothir and elles I were to blame
Wel bet than the by Ihu Absolone
Go forth thy wey or I wolle throwe a stone
And let me slepe a twanty deville wey
Allas quoth absalon and welle awey
That trewe loue was evir eville be set
Than kys me syn it may be no bet
For Ihus loue and for the loue of me
Wilt thou than goo thy wey ther wᵗith quod she
Ye certes lemmām quod this Absolon
Than make the redy quod she I come anon
And vnto Nicholas she seyde stille
Nowe pees and thou shalt laugh al thy fille
This Absalon doun set hym on his knees
And seyde I am alorde at al degrees
For aftir this I hepe there cōmmeth more
Lemmām thy grace and swete brid thyn ore
The wyndowe she vndoth and that in haste
Haue do quod she come of and spede the faste
Lest that our neyghtborys the aspye
This Absolon gan wype his mouth fulle drye
Derke was the nyght as piche or cole
And at the wyndowe she put out hir hole
And Absolon hym felt ne bet ne wors
But with his mouth he kyste hir ers
Fulle sauyrly or he were ware of this
A back he stirt and thought hit was amys
For welle wist he a womām had no berde
He felt a thynge al rowe and longe heride .
And seyde fye allas whate haue I do
Tehye quod she and clapped the wyndowe to
And absolon goth forth a sory paas
A berde aberde quod hende Nicholas
By goddes corpus this goth feire ⁊and welle
This sely Absolon herde euery dele
And on his lippes he gan for angre bite
And to hym selfe he seide I shalle the quyte
Who rubbeth nowe who froteth nowe his lyppes
Wᵗith dust wᵗith cloth wᵗith sonde with schippes
But absolon that seith fulle ofte allas
My soule betake I seide he to Sathanas
But me were leuyr than al this toun quod he
On this despite wroken for to be
Allas quod he allas that I ne had blent
His hote loue was cold and al queynt
For fro that tyme that he had kyst hir ars
Of paramoures set he not a cars
For he was helede of his maladye
Ful ofte ꝑper/paramours gan he defye
And wept as doth a childe that is bete
A softe paas he went hym oủer/re the strete
Vnto a smyth mēm called dan Gerueys
That in his forge smyteth plough harneys
He sharpeth the share and the cultre besely
This absolon knocketh alle esely
Of alle this pley ageyne no worde he yaf
He had nomore towh on his distaf
Than Geruays knewe and seide frende so dere
That hote cultre in the chymney here
As lene it me I haue therwith adone
And y wylle brynge it the ageyne fulle sone
Geruays answered / certes were hit golde
Or in a poke nobles al vntolde
Thou shuldest it haue as I am trewe smyth
Ey cristes foote whate wille ye do therewith
Therfore quod Absolon be as be may
I shalle welle telle hit the to morowe or day
And caught the cultre by the colde stele
Ful solfte out of the dore he gan stele .
And went vnto the Carpenters walle
He coughede firste and knocked therwᵗithalle
Vppou the wyndowe right as he did ere
This Alisou answered who is there
That knocketh so I warant hit athef
Why nay quod he god wote my swete lef
I am absolon thyn owne derlynge
O golde quod he I haue the brought arynge
My modir yaff it me so god me saue
Fulle fyne hit is and therto welle graue
This wolle hit is I gyue the yf thou me kysse
This Nicholas was risen for to pisse
And thought he wolde amende al the iape
He shuld kysse his ers or that he scape .
And vp the wyndowe did he hastely
And out his ars he putteth pryuely
Ouer the buttoke to the shanke bone
And ther with spake this klerke this Absolone
Speke swete brid I not where thou art
This Nicholas anone let fle a fart
A grete as he it had be a thondir dent
That wᵗith the stroke he was almost y blent
And he was redy with his Iren hote .
And Nicholas amyd the ers he smote
Of goth the skynne an honde brede aboute
The hote Cultre brende so his towte
And for the smert he wende for to dye
As he were wode for wo he gan to crye
Helpe water / water / helpe for goddes herte
This Carpynter out of his slombir sterte
And herde one crye water as he were wode
And thought allas nowe cometh the flode
He set hym vp wᵗithouten wordes mo
And with his axe he smote the corde a two
And doun goth al he fonde neithir to selle
Ne brede ne Ale l tille he cōmme to the selle .
Vppou the flore and there a swone he lay
Up stirt Alysou and Nicholay
And cryed out and harowe in the strete
The Neyghbores both smale and grete
In rennen for to gawryn on this man
That yet a swone lay both pale ⁊and wan
For with the falle brost hath he his arme
But stonde he muste vnto his owne harme
For whan he spake he was anone bore doune
With hende Nicholas and Alysoune
They tolde euery mām that he was woode
So he was agaste of Noes flode
Throwe fantasye that of his vanyte
He had bought hym knedynge tubbes thre
And had hem hangede in the rofe aboue
And that he prayde hem for goddes loue
To sitt in the rofe per compenye
The folke gan laughen at his fantasye
In to the roff thy kyken and they gape
And turned alle his harme vn to a iape
For whate so ever this Carpenter answerede
Hit was for nought nomām his resou herde
With othis grete he was swore downe
That he was holde wode in alle the towne
For euery clerke right anone helde wᵗith othir
They seide the mām was wode my leve brothir
And euery wight gan laugh at this striff
Thus swyuede was the carpenters wiff
For alle his kepynge and alle his ielosye
And Absolon hath kyssede her nethir ye
And Nicholas is scaldede in the toute
This tale is done and god saue al this route

(base) Of Absolon / and hende Nicholas
(base) Diuerse folk / diuersely they seyde
(base) But for the moore part they lowe and pleyde
(base) Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
(base) But it were oonly / Osewold the Reue
(base) By cause he was / of Carpenters craft
(base) A litel Ire / is in his herte ylaft
(base) He gan to grucche / and blamed it alite
(base) So the ik quod he / ful wel koude I thee quyte
(base) With bleryng of a proud Millerys Iye
(base) If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
(base) But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age
(base) Gras tyme is doon / my fodder is now forage
(base) This white top / writeth myne olde yerys
(base) Myn herte / is also mowled / as myne herys
(base) But if ik fare / as dooth an Openers
(base) That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers

div.l: (base) Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
(base) We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe
(base) For in oure wil / ther stiketh euere a nayl
(base) To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl
(base) As hath a leek / for thogh oure myght be goon
(base) Oure wil desireth folie / euere in oon
(base) For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
(base) Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke
(base) Foure gleedes haue we / whiche I shal deuyse
(base) Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
(base) Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
(base) Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
(base) But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth
(base) As many a yeer / as it is passed henne
(base) Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne
(base) For sikerlik whan ik was bore anon
(base) Deeth drogh the tappe of lyf / and leet it goon

(base) Vnder plesaunce and vnder bisy peyne

(base) And yeuen hym my trewe herte as fre

(base) With so heigh reuerence and as by his cheere

(base) That Fortune wolde that he moste twynne
(base) Out of that place which that I was Inne
(base) Wher me was wo that is no questioun
(base) I kan nat make of it descripsioun

(base) And eek that he repeyre sholde agayn

(base) And reson wolde eek that he moste go
(base) For his honour as ofte happeth so
(base) Wherfor I wold not ben ayein his honour

(base) And took it wel syn that it moste be

div.l: (base) Whan it cam hym to purpos for to reste
(base) I trowe he hadde thilke text in mynde
(base) That alle thyng repeiryng to his kynde
(base) Gladeth hymself thus seyn men as I gesse
(base) Men louen of propre kynde Newfangelnesse
(base) As bryddes doon that men in Cages feede
(base) For theigh thow nyght and day take of hem hede
(base) And strawe hir Cages faire and softe as sylk
(base) And yeue hem sugre hony breed and Milk
(base) Yet right anon as that his dore is vppe
(base) He with his feet wol sporne doun his cuppe
(base) And to the wode he wole and wormes ete
(base) So newfangel been they of hir mete
(base) And louen nouelries of propre kynde
(base) No gentilesse of blood may hem bynde
(base) So ferde this gentil tercelet allas the day
(base) Thogh he were gentil born and fressh and gay
(base) And goodlich for to seen and humble and free
(base) He saw vpon a tyme a kyte flee
(base) And sodeynly he loued this kyte so
(base) That al his loue is clene fro me ago
(base) And hath his trouthe falsed in this wise
(base) Thus hath the kyte my loue in hir seruyse
(base) And I am lorn withouten remedye
(base) And with that word this Faukon gan to crye
(base) And swowned eft in Canacees barm

div.l: (base) Out of the grownd and maken saues newe
(base) Of herbes preciouse and fyn of hewe
(base) To heelen with this hauk fro day to nyght
(base) She dooth hir bisynesse and al hir myght
(base) And by hir beddes heed she made a Muwe
(base) And couered it with veluettes blue
(base) In signe of trouthe that is in wommen sene
(base) And al withoute the Muwe is peynted grene
(base) In which were peynted alle thise false fowles
(base) As been thise tydyues terceletz and Owles
(base) Right for despit were peynted hem bisyde
(base) And Pyes on hem for to crye and chyde
(base) Thus lete I Canacee hir hauk kepyng
(base) I wol namoore as now speke of hir ryng
(base) Til it come eft to purpos for to seyn

(base) By mediacion of Cambalus

(base) That neuere yet was herd so greet meruailles
(base) First wol I telle yow of Cambyuskan
