div.l: (base) Here endith the Squyeres tale
and begynneth the mchantes ꝓprologe
WEpynge and waylynge care and other sorowe
I knowe ynough bothe even and eke a morowe
Quod the marchant and so doth othir mo
That weddid be I trowe that it be so
For wel I wote hit fareth so by me
I haue awyff the worst that may be
For thowe the fende coupled to hir were
She wolde hym oủer/remache I dar wel swere
Whate shuld I you reherse in special
Hir high malice she is a shrewe at al
There is as longe and a large difference
Betwix Grisildis grete pacientes
And of my wyff the passynge cruelte
Were I vnbounde also mot I the
I wold neuyr eft come in the snare
We weddid mēm lyue in sorowe and care
Asay who so wolle and he shalle fynde
That I sey soth be seynt thomas of Inde
As for the more part I sey not al
God shild that hit shuld so be falle
A good sir hoste I haue weddid be
This monthis two and nomore ꝑper/parde
And yet I trowe he that hath al his lyf
Weddid be though men wold hym ryf
In to the hert ne coude in no maner where
Telle somoche sorowe as I nowe here
Coude tel of my wyues cursidnes
Nowe quod our hoste marchant so god you blysse
Syn ye so mekyl konne of that art
Fulle he hertely I pray you telle vs part
Gladly quod he but of myn owne sore
For sory hert I may telle nomore
Here endeth the Marchauntes prologe
And begynneth his tale
SOm tyme there was dwellynge in lumbardy
A worthy knyght that borne was at pauy
In whiche he leuyd in grete prosperyte
And . lx . yere awyfles man was he .
And folowed his bodely delite
On womēm was his hole appetite
As done this folis that bene seculer
And whan that he was passed lx yere
Were hit for holynes or for dotage
I cannot sey but suche agrete corage .
Had this knyght to be aweddid man .
That day and nyght he doth alle that he can
To aspye where he myght weddid be
Praynge oure lorde grauntynge that he
Myght onys knowe that blysfulle lyff
That is betwix an housband and his wiff
And for to leue vndir the holy bonde .
With whiche god first mām and womām bonde
No nothir lyff seyde he is worth abene .
For wedlok is so esy and so clene .
That in this world hit is aparadyse .
Thus seyde this old knyght . that was so wyse
And certeynly as soth as god is kynge
To take a wyff is g glorious thynge .
And namly when aman is old and hore
Then is a wiff the fruyt of his tresore .
Than shuld he take a yonge wyff and a feire . / /
On whiche he myght engendir hym an heire
And lede his lyff in ioy and in solace .
Where as this bachelers syngen allas
When that they fynde eny aduersite .
In loue whiche that is but childes vanyte
And truly hit hitis sit welle welleso to be so
That bachelers haue ofte peyne and wo
On brotil grounde they bild brotilnes
They fynde frealte when they wene sikernes
They leue but is abrid or as abeste
In liberte and vndir none areste
There as aweddis mām is in astate
Lyueth his lyff blysfulle and ordinate
Vndir the yoke of maryage I bounde
Welle may his hert in ioy and blys habunde
For who can be so buxu as a wyff
Who is so trewe who is so tentiff
To kepe hym seke and hole and is his make
For wel or wo she wolnot hym forsake .
She is not wery hym to loue and serue
Though he lye bedred til he sterue .
And yet som clerkes seyne hit is not so
Of whiche Theophraste is one of tho
Whate force though Theophraste doth lye
Ne take no wyff quod he for housbandrye
As for to spare in houshold thyn expence .
A trew seruᵃnt doth more diligence
Thy good to kepe than doth thy selfe wiff
For she wolle clayme halfe part al her lyf
And yf that thou be seke . so god me saue .
Thy verry frendes or a trewe knaue .
Wolle kepe the bett / than she that wayteth ay
Aftir thy doth good and hath do many a day
But take no kepe of suche vanyte right
Do fy Theophraste and herken me .
A wyff is goddis yeft verely
Al othir maner . yeftis hardely
As londes rentes pasturys and cōmmune .
Of othir yeftis menable of fortune
That passen as a shadowe on awal
But drede not yf I pheynly speke shal .
A wiff wil laste and in thy hous endure right
Wel lenger than the lust ꝑper/parauenture
Maryage is a fulle grete sacramente
Who that hath no wyff is but shent
He leuyth helples and is al desolat
I speke of folke in seculer estate .
And herken why I sey not this for nought
The womām is for mannes helpe I wrought
The high god whan he had Adam maked
And sawe hym alone . bely naked
God of his grete goodnes / sayde than . right
Let vs nowe make an helpe to this man
Lyke to hym selfe . and than he made eve .
Here may ye se and here by preue .
That a wyff is mannes helpe and his comfort
His paradise terrestre and his disport
So buxum and so vertuous is she .
They must nedis leue in vnyte
O fleyshe they be and of o blode I gesse .
Not but one hert in wil and in distresse .
A wyf a saynte mary benedicite
Howe myght amām haue ony adủer/resite
That hath a wyf certeys I can not sey
The blys that is betwix he twey
There may no tonge . telle it or hert thynke .
If he be poure she helpeth hym to swynke .
She kepith his good and wastith it nevir a dele
And al that her housband lust she liketh welle
She seyth not ones nay whan he seith ye
Do this seith he . al redy sir seith she .
O blysfulle ordre O wedloke precious
Thou art so mery and eke so ioyous
And so cōmmendid and approued eke
That euery man that holdeth hym worth a leek
Vppon his bare knees ought alle his lyf
Thankynge his god that hym sent a wyf
Or elles pray god hym for to sende .
A wyf to laste to his lyues ende
For than his lyf is set in sikirnes
He may not be disceued as I gesse .
So that he worke aftir his wyues rede .
Than may he boldly bere vp his hede .
They be so trewe and therto eke so wyse
For whiche yf thou wolt worche as the wyse
Do alwey as the womām wol the rede
Lo howe Iacob as this clerkes rede .
By good councelle of his modir Rebek
Bonde the kyddys skyn aboute his nek
For whiche his fadirs benyson he wan
Lo Iudith as the story welle telle can .
By wyse councelle she goddis peple kept
And slowe hym Olofernus while he slept
Lo how Abigail . be good councelle that she
Sauede hir housband Nabal . whan that he .
Shulde haue be slayne and loke hester also
Be good councelle delyuered out of wo .
The peple of god and made Mardoche . / /
Of assure enhauncede for to be . / / right
There is no thynge in gre suꝑper/parlatif
As seith senek aboue an humble wiff right
Suffre thy wyues tonge as Caton bit
She shalle cōmmaunde and thou shalt suffre it
And yet she wille obey of curtesye
Awyff is keper of thy housbandrye
Welle may the seke mām be waile and wepe right
There as no wiff is the hous to kepe .
I warne the yf thou wisele wilt wirche . right
Loue welle thy wiff as crist loueth hir churche
If thou louest thy selfe thou louyst thy wyff
Nomām hatith his fleyshe but in his lyff
He suffreth it and therfore bid I tho .
Cheryshe thy wiff or thou shalt neủer/re the
Housband and wiff whate so mēm iape or pley
Of worldly folke holden the right wey
They bene knytt there may no harme betide
And namly on the wyffes side
For whiche this Ianuiary of whiche I tolde .
Considrith hath in his dayes olde
The lusty lyff the vertuos quyete
That is in maryage holy swete .
And for his frendes on a day he sent
To telle the effect of his entent
With face sad he hath his tale to hem tolde
He seydes frendes I am hoor and olde
And almost god woot at my pittis brynke
Vppon my soule somwhate must I thynke
I haue my body folily dispended
I blessed be god hit shalle be amendid
For I wolle certeyn certeynbe a weddid man . / /
And that in alle the hast that I can
Vnto som mayde feir and tendir of age
I pray you shapeth for my maryage
Alle sodeynly for I wilnot abide .
And I wille fonde to aspye on my syde
To whom I may be weddid hastely
But for asmoche as ye be mo than I
Ye shulle rather suche athynge a spyen
Than I and where me lyst best alyen
But o thynge I warne my frendes dere
I wille no nothir wiff haue in no manere
She shalnot passe . xvj yere certeyn
Olde fleysh wold haue yonge fleysh fayn
Bet is a pike than a pikerel
Better than old oldfleyshe beff is tendir vele
I wol no womām of twanty yere of age .
Hit is but bene strawe and grete forage
And eke this old wydowes god it wote
The can so mykyl craft of wadis bote
So mykyl harme what that hem list
That withem shold I neuyr lyue in rest
For sondry scoles makith subtil clerkes
Womām of many a scole halfe a clerke is
But certeynly a yonge thynge may men gye
Right as a mām with handis warm wax plye
Therfore I sey you pleynly in a clause .
I wole non old wiff haue for this thiscause
For yf so were yf y hadde suche myschaunce
That I in hir coude haue no plesaunce
Than shuld I lede my lyf in a voutrye
And so streyght to d the deuyl whan I dye
Ne children shuld I none on hir getyn / / Yet had I leuyr
Yet had I leuir houndis had me eten .
That myn heritage shulde be falle .
In strange honde and thus I telle you alle
I doute not I wote the cause why
Men shuld wed and furthirmore wote I
There speketh many mēm of mariage
That wote nomore of hit than doth my page
For whiche causes men shuld take takeno a wyff
If he may not chast be . be his wyf
Take hym awyfe . with grete deuocion
Be cause of lefful procreacion
Of childryn to the honoᵘur of god aboue .
And not only for ꝑper/paramour ne for loue .
And for they shuld lechery eschewe
And yelde hir dett while hit is nowe
Or for that eche mām shuld helpe othir
In myscheff as the sustir shal the brothir
And leue in chastite ful heuenly
But sirs be your leue that am not I
For god be thanked I dar make avaunt
I fere my lymys starke and sufficiaunt
To do alle that amām loueth to do
And am stronge ynough to ride or go
Though I behoor and fare as doth a tre
That blosmeth or that the tre grene be
A blosmed tre is neythir dry ne dede .
I fele me no where hoor / but on myn hede
My hert and my lemys is ay grene .
As laurer that through the yere is sene
And sithnys ye haue herde . al myn entent
I pᵃy you that to my wille . ye assent
Dyuers men dyuersly hym tolde . / /
Of mariage many ensamples olde
Some blamed hit som pᵃycede hit certeyn
But at the last shortly forto seyn
As alday fallith altercacion
Betwix frendes in disputacion
There fille a striff betwix his brethirn two
Of whiche that one was cleped placebo
Placebo seyde O Ianuary brothir
To you telle I this tale and to no nothir
Fulle litle nede had ye my lorde so dere
Councel to axe of eny that is here
But that ye be on so ful of sapience .
That you ne liketh for yoᵘur high prudence
To weyue fro the worde of Salamon .
This worde seide he to vs euerychon
Worke al thynge . be councel thus seyde he
And than shalt not thou repent the .
But though Salamo spake suche aworde
Myn owne dere brothir and my lorde .
So wyshely god my soule brynge to reste
I holde youre owne councel . for the beste
For brothir myn of me take this motif
I haue be a courtmām al my lyff
And yet god wote thowe I vnworthy be
I haue stonde in fulle grete degree
Aboute lordes in fulle grete astate .
Yet had I neuyr wᵗith none of hem debate
I neuyr contraryed hem truly
I wote wel that my lorde can more than I
Whate that he he seith I hold hit ferme ⁊and stable
I sey the same . or othir thynge semblable .
A fulle grete foole is ony councellour
That serueth a lorde of high honour
That dar presume or onys thynke hit
That his councelle shuld passe . his lordis wit
Nay lordis be no folys be my fey
Ye haue youre silue spoken here to day
So high sentence so holy and so welle
That I consent and conferme euery dele .
Youre wordes and alle youre oppynyon
Be god ther is nomore in this toun
Ne in ytaille coude bettir haue sayd
Crist holdeth hym of this fulle wel paid
And truly hit is an high corage .
Of eny man that stept is in age .
To take a yonge wiff for by my fadir kyn
Youre hert hongeth vpon a ioly pyn
Doth nowe in this mater as you list
For fynally I holde hit for the best
Iustynus that ay sate fulle stille and playde
He right on this wyse to placebo seide .
Nowe brothir myn quod he . be pacient I pray
Syn ye haue seyde herken whate I sey
Seneke amonge othir wordes wyse
Seith that a mām ought hym right wel avise
To whom he yeueth his good or his catelle .
And sithnes I ought me auyse right welle
To whom I yeue my good a wey fro me
Wel more I ought for to avise me
To whom I yeue my body for alwey
I warne you welle hit is no childis pley
To take awyff withouten avisement
Me must enqueren this is myn assent
Whedir she be wise sobir or dronkelewe .
An out goer or othir wey a shrewe .
A chidar or a waster of thy good
Riche or poure or of maners wode
Al be it so that noman fynde shall
None in this world that trotteth hole in al
Ne mām ne best suche as mēm can deuyse
But neuyrtheles / hit ought ynough suffice
With eny yf so were that she had
Mo good vertues than vices bad
And al this axed leyser to enquere .
For god hit wote I haue wept ful many a tere
Fulle pryuely syn I had a wyf
Preyse who so wolle a weddis mannys lyff

And begynneth the Pardeners Prologe
LOrdynges quod he in churches whēm I preche
I peyne me to haue an hauten speche
I ryynge it out as rounde as goth a belle
For I can be roote alle that I telle .
My teme is evir one and awey was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas . / /
First I pronıı̄unce whens that I come
And then my billis showe I alle ⁊and sōmme
Oure lordes seale is my patent
That showe I first my body to warant
That nomām be so bolde ne prest ne clerke
Me to distourde of cristis holy werke . / /
And aftir that telle I forth my tales
Bulles of Popes and of Cardynalles
Of Patriarkes and bysshoppes I showe
And in latyn speke wordes a fewe
To saueren with my predicacou
And for to stere men / to deuocioun
Then showe I forth my longe cristalle stones .
I crāmmyd in clotes fulle of bones
Reliques they bene as wenyn they echone
Then haue I in a laton a shuldre bone
Whiche that was an holy Iewes shepe
Good mēm sey I take of my wordes kepe .
If that this bones be weysshe in eny welle
If cowe or calfe / shepe or Oxe swelle .
That eny worme hath eten or hym stonge
Touche he this bone anone he shal be sonde
And yet also more firthirmore
Of pockes and of scabbes and every sore
Shalle euery shepe be hole that of this welle
Drynketh a draught take kepe of that I telle
Wolle euery wight or that the cok croweth
And wold do eny thynge that hy oweth
Fastynge drynke of this welle a draught
As that holy Iewe oure eldirs taught
His bestis and his store shalle multiplye
And sirs also hit helith iolousye
And though amām be falle in Ielouse rage
Lett make with this watir his potage
And nevir shalle he more his wyfe mystrust
Though he the defaute by hir wist
Al had she take prestis two or thre
Here is a meteyne eke ye maye se . / /
He that his honde wol put in that meteyn
He shalle haue multipleynge of his greyn
When he hath sowen be hit whete or otis
So that he offre pens or ellis grotis
And mēm a womēm o thynge warne I you
If eny wight be in this churche nowe
That hath done synne horrible that he
Dar nat for shame shryven be
Or eny womām be she yonge or olde
That hath made hir housband cokolde
Suche folke shalle haue no powere ne gᵃce
To offre to my Reliques in this place
And who so fyndeth hym out of suche blame
Cometh and offre in goddis name .
And I assoyle hem be the auctoryte
Suche as by bulle was gᵃunted me
By this werke haue I wonne many a yere
An hundred marke syn I was pardenere
I stonde like a clerke in my pulpitt
And showe lewde peple and doun they sitt
I preche so as ye haue herde before
And telle an hundred iapes more
Than peyne I me to streche forth my necke
And est and west vpon the people I becke
As doth a dove sittynge vpon a berne .
Myn hondes and my tonge gone so yerne
That it is ioy to se my besynes
Of avaryce and suche cursidnes
Is alle my prechynge to make hem fre
To yeue their pens and namly vnto me .
For myn entent ys not but for to wynne
And nothynge for correccou of synne .
I recke not when that they be buryede
Though her soules gone a blakberyede
For certes many a predicacou
Sawneth som tyme of evill entenciou
Som for plesaunce of folke and for flatrye
To bene avauncede be ypocresye
And som for vaynglory and som for hate
For whan I dar not othir while debate
Then wil I stynge hem wᵗith my tonge smert
In prechynge so that they shul not a stert
To bene defamede falsly yf that he
Hath trespacede othir to my brethirn or me
For though I tel not his propre name
Men shal wel knowe hit is the same
By symonye or by othir circıı̄unstauncis
Thus quytt I folke that doth vs displesaunces
Thus spitt I out my venyn vnder hewe
Of holynes to seme holy and trewe
But shortly myn entent I wille devise .
I preche of nothynge but of couetise
Therfore my teme ys yet and ever was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas .
Thus gan I preche the same wyse
To suche as be vsynge to syn of avaryse
But though my selfe be gilty in that syn
Yet can I make othir folke to twynne
From Auaryce and to sore repent
But that is not my pryncypal entent /
I preche no thynge but for couetise
Of this mater hit ought ynough suffice
Then telle I of ēmnsamples many one
Of olde storyes longe tyme gone
For lewde people louen talis olde
Whiche thynges can they wel report ⁊and holde
Whate trowe ye whiles that I may pche
And for to wynne golde and siluere for to teche
That I wille leue in pouert wilfully
Nay Nay I thought hit nevir truly
For I wolle preche and begge in sondry londes
I wille do no laboure with my hondes
And make basketes and leue therby
By cause I wilnot begge ydilly
I wil none of the appostles countirfete
Al were it yeven of the porest page .
Or of the powrest wydowe in a village
Alle shuld hir children sterue for famyne
Nay I wille drynke the lycoure of the wyne
And haue a ioly wenche in euery towne
But herkeneth lordynges in concluciou
Youre likynge is that I shalle telle a tale
Nowe I haue dronke a draught of corny ale
By god I hope I shal telle you a thynge
That shal be resou be at your lykynge .
For though my selfe be a ful vicōmus man
A moralle tale I you telle cal can
Whiche I am wont to pche for to wyn
Nowe holde youre peace my tale I begyn

Here endeth the Pardeners Prologe
And begynneth the Pardeners tale
IN flaundres somtyme was a compenye
Of yonge folke that haunten folye
As ryot / hasarders . stewes and tavarnes
And pley the harlottꝭes in many hurnes
They daunce and pley at dyse day and nyght
And eten and drynken abouen her myght
Through whiche they done the deuys sacryfice
Withyn the deuylles temple in sundry wice .
The suꝓprofluyteys abhomynable .
Here othes be so grete and dampnable
That hit is grysly for to here hem swere
Oure blessid lordes body al to tere
Hem thought the Iewes rent hy not ynough
And eche of hem at othirs synne lough
And right anone come the tombleres
Fete and smale and yonge frutestres
Syngers wᵗith harpes . bawdes . waffres
Suche as ben the verey deuylls officers
To kyndille and blowe the fire of lechery
That is annexede vnto gloteny
The holy wrytt take I to wytnes
That lechery is in wyne and dronknes
Howe that dronken lott vnkyndely
Lay by his doughters two vnwetyngly
So dronke he was he nyst whate he wrought
And therfore sore repent hym ought
Of herodes who so wolle the storyes seche
There may he lerne ⁊and by ensamples teche
Whan he of wyne was replete at his feste
Ryght at his owne table yaue his heste
To sle the baptist Iohn fulle giltles . / /
Seneke seith eke good wordes doutles
He seith he can no difference fynde
Betwix a mām that is out of his mynde
And a mām that is dronkelewe
But that wodnes that fallen is in a shrewe
ꝐPer/Parceuereth lenger than doth dronknes
O gloteny fulle of cursidnes
O cause first of our confucioun
O originalle of oure ꝑper/pardicioun
Til crist had bought vs wᵗith his blode ageyne
Lo howe dere and shortly was to seyne
Abought was this curside vilonye .
Corrupt was alle this worlde through glotenye
Adam oure first fadir in his lyfe also ⁊and his wyfe also
Fro paradyse to laboure and to woo
Were dryven for that vice it is no drede
For whiles that Adam fastede as I rede
He was in paradyse and whan that he
Ete of the fruyt defended on the tre
Anone he was out caste to wo ⁊and peyne
O glotenye on the ought vs alle to cāmpleyne
O wist amām howe many maladyes
Foloweth of excesse and of glotonyes
He wolde be the more mesurable .
Of his diete syttynge at his table
Allas the short throte the tendir mouth
Maketh that est and west north and soth
In erth in eire in water men to swynke
To gete a glotou mete and drynke
O poule of this mater wolle canst thou endite
Mete vnto wombe and wombe vnto mete
Shalle god destroy both as Poule seith
Allas a foole thynge hit is be my feith
To sey this worde / and fouler is the dede
When men so drynketh of the white ⁊and rede
NOwe wolle I speke of othis fals and grete
A worde or two as many bokes trete
Grete swerynge is a thynge Abhomynable
And fals swerynge is a thynge more repreuable
The high god forbade swerynge at alle
Wytnes of mathewe but in specialle
Of swerynge seith holy Ieromye
Thou shalt swere soth thyn othes ⁊and not lye
And swere in dome and rightwysnes .
But ydle swerynge is a cursidnes .
Beholde and se that in the first table
Of high goddis hestis honourable
Howe that the secounde heste of hy is this
Take not my name yn ydilnes amys
Lo rathir he forbedith suche swerynge
Or homycyde or eny cursid s thynge
I sey as by ordre thus hit stondeth
This knoweth they that his hestis vnderstondeth
Howe that the secounde hest of god is that
And firthirmore I wil the telle at platt
That vengeaunce shal not part from the hous
That of his othis is outrageous .
Ey by goddis precious hert and by his nayles
And by blode that is in hayles
Seven ys my chaunce and thyne fyue ⁊and thre
Ey goddys Armys yf thou falsly pley wᵗith me
This gadder shalle through thyne hert go
This fruyt cometh of the bichede bonys two .
For swerynge Ire . falsnes . and homycide .
Nowe for the loue of criste that for vs dyede
Leueth youre othes both gret and smale .
For cristis sake and herkeneth my tale .
This ryatours thre of whiche I telle .
Longe or to pⁱrime were ronge eny belle
Were sett hem in a tavarde to drynke
And as they sate / the herde abelle rynge
Before a cors was cariede to his gᵃue
That one of hem gan calle to his knaue
Go bett quod he and axe redely
Whate cors is this that passith forth by
And loke that thou report his name welle
Sir quod the boy hit nedeth nevir a dele .
Hit was me tolde or ye come here two hourys
He was ꝓprode an olde felowe of yourys
Al sodeynly was he slayne to nyght
For dronke as he sate on his benche vp right
There came a pⁱriuey thefe men clepe deth
That in this countre al peple sleyth
And with his spere he smote his hert in two
And went his weye withoutēm wordes moo
He hath a thousand slayne this pestilence .
And maystir or ye come in his psence
Me thynketh hit were necessarye
For to be ware of suche an aduersarye
Deth is redy for to meete hym eủer/re more
Thus taught me my dame I sey nomore
O seynt mary seide this tauernere
The childe seith soth for he hath this yere
Hens ouer a myle slayne in a grete village .
Both man and womām childe and page .
I trowe his habitaciou be there
To be avycede grete wisdame hit were
Or that he did amām a dishonoure
Ye goddis armes seide this Ryatoure
Ys hit suche perylle with hym to meete
I shalle hym seeke by dale and eke by strete .
I shalle hym sle by goddes digne bones
Herken felowes we thre bene all onys
Let eche of vs become othirs brothir
And eche of vs holde vp his honde to othir
And we shalle sle this traytour deth
He shalbe slayne he that so many sletth
By goddis dignyte or hit be nyght
To gedir haue this thre her hertis hight
To leue and dye eche of them wᵗith othir
As thowe he were his owne sworo brothir
And vp they stirt al dronken in this rage
And for they gone taward that village .
Of whiche the taverner . hath spoke beforne
And many a grysly oth haue they sworne .
And cristes blessid body they alle to rent
Deth shalle be dede and we may hym hent
When they haue gone not fully a myle
Ryght as they wold / haue gone oủer/re a style
An olde poure man fulle mekely hem gret
And seyde lordyngis / god you se
The prowdest of this ryatours thre
Answerde whate Carle wᵗith harde grace .
Why art thou al forwrappede saue thy face .
Why leuest thou so longe in so grete Age
This olde man gan loke in her visage
And seyde thus for I cannot fynde .
Aman thowe I walke in to ynde
Neither in Cite ne in village .
That wol chaunge his youth for myn age /
And therfore must I haue myn age stille
As longe tyme as hit is goddis wille
Ne doth allas wolnot haue my lyfe .
Thus walke I like a recheles caytefe
And on the gronde which is my modirs gate
I knocke with my staff erly and late .
And sey leve modir let me ynne
Lo howe I vanyssh fleysh blode and skynne
Allas whan shalle my body be at rest
Modir with you wold I chaunge in chest
That in my chambir longe tyme hath be .
Ye for a heyr cloute to wrappe yn me
But yet to me she wilnot do that gᵃce
For which fulle pale and wreched is my face
And sirs to you hit is no curtesye
To speke to an olde man vilenye
But I trespas in worde or in dede
Ye may your selfe in holy wrytt rede
A yenst an olde mām hore vpon his hede
Ye shuld be avisede wherfore I you rede .
Ne doth to no olde mām harme nowe .
Nomore that ye wolde men did to you
In age If ye shuld longe abide
And god be with where ye goo or ride
I must go thedir as I haue to do
Nay ald chorle be god thou shalt not so .
Seyde this othir hasardour anone .
Tho partest not so lightly by seynt Iohn
Thou spakyst right nowe of that traytoᵘur deth
That in this countre al oure frendes sleth
Haue here my trouth thou art his aspye
Tel where he is or thou shalt dye
By god and by the holy sacrament
Shortly thou art one of his assent
To sle vs yonge folke thou false thefe
Nowe sirs yf that it be to you lefe
To fynde deth turne vp this croked laue wey
For in that groue I sawe hy last be my fey
Vndir a tre and there he wolle abide .
For youre boste he wille no thynge hy hyde
Se ye that Oke right there ye shulle hym fynde
God saue you that bought alman kynde .
And you amende thus seide this old man
And euery of this ryatours so they ran
Tille they came to the tre and there the founde
Of floreyns fyne gold I coyned rounde
Wel nygh an eyght boysshelles as hem thought
No lenger than after deth they sought
But eche of them so glad was of that sight
For that the floreyns so feire were and bryght
That done they sate by the precious hourde
The worst of hem he spake the first worde
Brethirne quod he take kepe whate I sey
My wytt is grete though I bourde and pley
This tresoure hath fortune vnto vs yeuen .
In myrth and Iolite oure lyfe to lyuen .
And lightly as hit commeth so wall we spende
Ey goddis precious dignyte who wende
To day that we shuld haue so feire a grace
But myght this golde be caryed fro this place
Home to my hous or elles vnto youres
Then myght we sey a that hit were alle oures
Then were we in high felicite
But truly by day it may not be
Men wolde sey that we were theves stronge
And for oure owne tresure done vs honge .
This tresure must in be caryede be nyght
As wysely and as slyly as hit myght
Wherefore I rede let loke amonge vs alle .
Drawe kutt lett se where hit wol falle .
He that hath the shortist kutt wᵗith hert blythe
Shalle ren to towne and that ful swythe
To brynge vs brede and wyne fulle pⁱriuely
And two of vs shalle kepe ful subtilly
This tresoure welle and yf he wilnot tary
When it is nyght we shal this tresoure cary
Be one assent where as vs lyst best
That one of hem brought strawe in his fist
And bade hem drawe ⁊and loke on whom it wol falle
And it fille on the yongest of hem alle
And forth tawarde the towne he went anone
And also sone as he was gone
That one of hem spake thus vnto that othir
Thou wotist wol that oure felowe is gone thou art my sworen brothir
Thy profitt wol I telle the / right anone
Thou wotist wel that oure folowe is gone
And here is golde and that fulle grete plente .
That shalle be departed amonge vs thre
But natheles yf I can shape it so
That it departed were amonge vs two
Had I not done a frendes turne to the
That othir answerd y not howe it myght be
I wote wel the gold shalbe ourys two
Whate shalle we sey whate shulle we do
Shalle it be counceil seide the first shrewe
And I shalle telle the in wordes fewe
Whate we shul do and bryng hit wel aboute
I graunt quod that othir out of doute
That be my trouth I wil not the bewreyen
Nowe quod he thou wotist wol we be tweyn
And tweyne of vs shalle strenge be than one
Aryse as though thou woldest wᵗith hym pley
And I shal ryve hym through the sides twey
Whiles thou strouglest withym in game
And with thy daggir loke thou do the same
And then shalle alle this golde departed be
My dere frende betwix the and me .
Then may we both our lustes fulfille
And pley at dyse right at our owne wille
And thus accorded be this shrewes twey
To sle the thred as ye haue herde me sey
This yongest whiche that went to the town
Fulle ofte in hert he rolled vp and down
The beaute of this floreynes newe ⁊and bryght
O lorde quod he If so were that I myght
Al this tresoure wyn to my selfe alone
There nys no mām that leueth vndir trone .
O god that shulde leue as mery as y
And at last the fende oure enemy
Put in his hert that he shuld poysou by
Wᵗith whiche he myght sle his felowes twey
For why the fende founde hym in suche leuynge
That he had leue hym in sorowe to brynge
For this was vttirly his entent
To sle hem both and never to repent
And forth he goth no lenger wold he tary
In to the towne vnto a potecary
And prayde hym that he wolde hym selle
Som poysou that he myght his rattes quelle
And eke therwᵗith thero was a polcatt in his haw
That as he seide his capons had slawe .
And seide he wolde wreke hem yf he myght
On vermyn that destroyede hem be nyght
The Potecary answered thou shalt haue
A thynge as wyssly god my soule saue
In alle this world there is no creature
That eten or drynken hath of this confecture
Not but the mountenaunce of a corne of whete
That he ne shalle anone his lyfe forlete .
Ye sterve he shalle and that in lasse while
Or thou wolt goo passynge halfe a myle
The poysou is so stronge and so violent
This cursid mām hath in his holde it hent
And swyth in to the strete vnto aman
As fast as ever he myght he ranne
And borowde hym large botelles thre
And in to tweyne the poysou poured he
The thred he kept clene for his drynke .
For alnyght he shepe hym for to swynke .
In carynge of this golde out of this place
And when this ryatoure with sory grace
Had filled fulle this botelles thre
To his felowes ayen repeyreth he .
Whate nedith it to sermone of hit more
For right as they had cast his deth before
Ryght so they haue hym slayne right anone
And whan this was done then spake that one
Nowe lett vs sitt and drynke and make vs merye
And aftirwarde we wille his body burye
And aftirwarde hit happed hym ꝓpro caas .
To take the botel . there the poysou was
And dranke and yaue his felowe drynke also
For whiche anone they sterven both two .
But certes I suppase . that Auycenne
Wrot nevir in no Canon ne in na fene
More wondir sorowes of enpoysonynge
Thus had this wreches two her endynge
Thus ondid be this homysides two
And the false enpoysoner also
O cursid synne fulle of cursidnes
O traytours homysides O wickednes
O gloteny O luxury O hasardry
Thou blasphomer of crist wᵗith vilony
And othes grote of vsage and of pⁱride
Allas mankynde howe may it betide
That to thy creatoure whiche that he wrought
And with his precious blode the bought
Thou art so false and so vnkynd allas
Nowe good men god / foryeue you yoᵘur trespas
And ware you from the synne of Auaryse
My holy pardou may you alle warysshe
So that ye offre nobles or sterlynges
Or elles siluere sponys broches or rynges
Bowe youre hedes vndir this holy bulles
Cometh vp ye wyves offreth of yoᵘur wolles
Youre names I entre in my rolle anone .
In to the blis of heven shalle ye gone .
I you asseyle be my highe powere
You that wolle offre as clene and as clere
As ye were bore lo sirs thus I preche
And Ihu crist that is oure soules leche
So graunt you his pardou to receyue
For that is best I wille you not deceyue
But sirs o worde forgate I in my tale
I haue reliques and ꝑper/pardou in my male
As feire as eny man in Englonde
Whiche were me yeue of the popes honde

But ꝑper/paraventure
he hath suche angre and suche wrath to vs warde because
of oure offence //

that he wolle enioyne vs suche peyne that
we may not bere hit ne susteyne hit //

And therfore noble
lady we beseche youre noble piete

to take suche avisement
in this nede / that we ne oure Frendes be not disherited

CErtes seide dame Prudence it is and hard thyng
and right peryllous

that amām put hym selfe
alle vttirly in arbitraciou and Iugement and in þᵉ
myght and power of his enmy //

For Salamōm seith
Beleue me and gyue credence to that I shalle sey

Ne
yeue nevir the power ne gouernauᵃnce of thy goodes
to thy son / to thy wiff / to thy frende / ne to thy brothir

ne yeue thou myght ne maystry ouyr thy body whi-
les thou lyueste //

Nowe sith that he defendeth that a mām
shuldnot to his brothir ne to his frende the myght
of his body /

by a strenger reson he defendeth a man
to yeue hym to his enemy /

And natheles I counceille
you that ye mystrust not my lorde //

For I wote welle
and knowe veryly that he is debonair / meke / large /
and curteys /

and nothynge desyrous ne couetouse
of good ne riches //

For there is no thynge in this world
that he desireth more than worshippe and honỏer/re //

Fir-
thirmore I knowe and am fulle sure that he shall
no thynge do in this dede withouten my counceille

And I shalle so werke in this case that by the grace
of oure lorde god ye shalbe reconsiled vnto vs /

Then /
seide they with one voyce worshipfulle lady we put vs and
oure goodes in youre wille and disposiciou alle fullly

And
be redy for to come whate day that ye lyke to youre nobles
to assigne vs

for to make oure obligacōmns and bondes
also stronge as hit shalle like vnto youre godnes

that
we may fulfille the wille of you and my lorde Mellebe

Whan dame Prudence had herde the answers of this
mēm // She bade hem reterne ageyne pryuely //

And she re-
torned ageyne to hir lorde Mellebe // And tolde hy howe
howe she fonde his adversaryes fulle repentant //

know-
legynge fulle lowly her synnes and trespas / ⁊and howe þᵗat
they were redy to suffre alle peyne

requyrynge hym
of mercy and pite //

Then seide Mellebe / he is worthy to
haue ꝑper/pardou and foryevenes that excuseth hy not of
his synne //

But knowlageth and repenteth hy axyng
indulgence for his synne //

]Seneke seith There ys
the remyssion and foryeuenes //

For the confessiou ys
Neighbore to Innocence //

And therfor I assent and cōm-
forme me to haue pees

But hit is good that we do
not withoute the wille of oure Frendes /. ~~ ~~

Than was Prudence right glad and ioyfulle ⁊and
seyde

certes sir ye haue welle and goodly an-
swered

For right as by the councelle assent and helpe
of oure frendes ye haue stered to do venge you and
make werre /

right so withoutēm her councelle shalle
ye not accorde you ne haue pees wᵗith youre adủer/resaryes

For the lawe seyth There is no thynge so good by wey
of kynde as a thynge to be vnbonde be hym that it
was bounde //

And then dame Prudence wᵗithouten de-
lay or tarynge sent anone her Messyngers for her kyn
and her olde frendes / whiche were trewe and wyse

And tolde hem by ordre in presence of Mellebe all this
Me-lebe . alle this mater as ys expressede aboue and declared

And praide hem that they wolde sey her aduyse and con-
celle whate were beste to do in this nede //

And when Mel-
lebes frendes had herde this nede / and taken her aduy-
se and delyberacōmn of the forseide mater /

and had exa-
myned by grete besynes and grete counceille /

they
yaue fulle counceille for to haue pees and reste //

And þᵗat
Mellebe shuld receue wᵗith good hert his aduersaries to for-
yeuenes and mercy //

And when dame Prudence had
herde thassent of her lorde Mellebe and of his frendes

she
was wondirly glad in her hert and seyde //

There is ano-
ble proverbe that seith / the goodnes that thou mayste
do this day do hitt /

And abide not ne delay hit not til
tomorowe /

And therfore I councelle that ye sende youre
Messyngers suche as be discrete and wise

vnto yoᵘur aduer-
saryes / tellynge hem on youre behalfe /

that yf they will
trete of peace and of acorde /

that they shape hem wᵗith
withoutēm delay or tarynge to come vnto vs //

whiche
thynge ꝑper/parformed was in dede //

And whan this trespasoᵘurs
and repentynge folke of her folies / that is to sey the Ad-
uersaries of Mellebe /

had herde whate this messyngers
seide vnto hem /

they were right glad and ioyfulle ⁊and
answered fulle mekely and benignely

yeldynge gra-
ces and graces and thankes to her lorde Mellebe ⁊and
to alle his compeny //

And shopen hem withoutēm eny
delay to go wᵗith the messyngers and obey to the com-
maundement of her lorde Mellebe //

And right ano-
ne they toke her wey to her lordes court

and toke wᵗith hem
som of her trewe frendes to make feith for hem And for
to be theire borowes /

And when they were come to the
presence of Mellebe / he seide to them thise wordes /

hit
stondeth thus seide Mellebe and soth hit is that

cause-
les and wᵗithoutēm skylle and resou

ye haue done grete
Iniuryes to me to my wiff Prudence / and to my
doughter also //

For ye haue entred to my hous by
violence

and haue done suche outrage / that almēm
knowe wel that ye haue deserued deth //

And ther-
fore wold I knowe of you

whedir ye wille put you
to punyshynge and the chastisynge and the venge-
ance of this outrage in the wille of me and of my wif

THen the wisest of hem thre answered for hem
alle And seide

sir / we knowe welle that we
be vnworthy to come to the court of so grete a lorde
and so worthy as ye be

For we haue so gretly mys-
taken vs ⁊and haue offended and gilted in suche wise
ageynste youre high lordeship

that truly we haue
deserued the deth /

but for the grete goodnes And
debonairte that alle the world witnesseth of your
ꝑper/parsone /

we submytte vs to the excellence ⁊and benyg-
nyte of yoᵘur gracious lordeschip

and besechynge you
of youre merciable pite ye wille considre oure gre-
te repentance and lowe submyssiou

and graunt
vs forgeuesse of oure outrageous trespas and offen-
sis /

For we knowen that yoᵘur liberalle grace and mcy
strechen ferther in to goodnes / that doth oure outrage-
ous giltes and trespaces in to wyckednes //

Alle be hit
that cursedly and dampnably we haue agilted and
Agreuede youre high lordeshippe ~~~ ~~~ ~~ ~~ ~~
THan Mellebe toke hem from the grounde fulle benigly

and receyuede her obligacions and boundis by her
Othis vppon her plegis and borowes

And assigned hem
a certeyne day to retorne vnto his court

for to receyue and
accept the Iugement that Mellebe wold cōmmaund to be
done on hem by the causes afore seide /

whiche thynges
ordeyned / eủer/rey man retorned / to his owne hous //

And whām
Dame Prudence sawe hir tyme / She feyned and axede
hir lorde Mellebe /

Whate vengeance he thought to take
vppon his Aduersaryes

To the whiche Mellebe answered
and seyde Certes I thynke and purpos me fully

to dyshe-
rite hem of alle that euyr they haue and put hem in ex-
ile for euyrmore

Certes seide Dame Prudence / this we-
re a cruel sentence and moche ageynst reson

For ye be
riche ynough and haue no nede of othir mennes goodꝭes

And ye myght fulle lightly in this wise gete you a ful
couetous name /

whiche is a vicious leuynge And
ought to be eschewed of euery good man .

For after the
worde of the apostle Couetise is the rote of alle har-
mes //

And therfore hit were bettir to you to lese somo-
che good of youre owne / than for to take of her goodes
in this maner

For bettir hit is to lese good wᵗith worship
than hit is to wynne good wᵗith vilony and shame

And
euery man ought to do his diligence and besynes to
gete hym a good name /

And yet shalle he not hooly
besye hym in kepynge of his good name /

But he shal
alwey enforce to do som thynge by the whiche he may
renouele or renewe his good name

For hit is written
that the old good loos of a man or good name is sone
gone and passed / when hit is not renowed ne reno-
veled /

And as touchynge that ye sey ye wille exile
youre aduersaryes /

that thynketh me moche ageyn reson and
out of mesure /

considerynge the power that they haue . yeve
you vppon hem selfe //

And yet hit is written that he ys
worthy to lese his preuele that mysuseth the myght and
the power that is yeue hym //

And I set caas that ye myght
enyoyne hem that peyne be right and by lawe //

whiche
that I trowe ye may not do /

I sey ye ought not to put hit
to execucou / For ꝑper/parauenture

than were hit lyke to retor-
ne to the werre as hit was before //

And therfore yf ye
wolle that men do you obesauᵃnce / ye must demene you
more curteysly /

this is to sey ye muste yeue more easy pe-
nance and Iugement

For hit is written that he that
most curteysly cōmmaundeth / to hym men moste obey

And
therfore I pᵃy you that in this necessite and in this nede
ye caste you for to ouercome your hert /

For Seneke seith
he that oủer/recometh his hert / ouercometh twyes /

And
Tul-lius seith There is no thynge so cōmmendable in a grete
lorde

as whan he is debonair and meke and appeseth
hym lightly //

And I pray you that ye wille nowe for-
bere to do vengeaunce

in suche a maner that your
good name may be kept and conserued /

And that mēm
may haue cause and mater to prayse you of pite And
of mercy //

And that ye haue no cause to repent you
of thynge that is done

For Seneke seith / he oủer/recōmmeth
an euyl maner that repenteth hym of his victory //

wher-
fore I pray you let mercy be in youre herte

to theffect
And to thentente that god almyghty haue mercy on
you in his laste Iugement

For seynt Iames seith in
his Epistlys Iugement withouten mercy shal be done
to hym that hath no mercy on a nothir wight / ~~ / ~~ /

WHan Mellebe had herde the grete skylles and resons
of dame Prudence And hir wise informacōmns
And techynges

his hert began tenclyne to the wille .
of his considerynge her grete entent

conformed hym anone .
and assented to worke aftir hir couneille /

And thanked god
of whom procedith alle goodnes and vertu that hym hath
sent a wyff of so grete discression //

And when the day cam
that his aduersaryes shuld appere in his presence //

He
spake to hem fulle goodly / And seyde in this wyse / .

¶ Alle be
hit so that of your pride and presumpcōmn and hye folye
of youre neclygence and vnkonnynge

ye haue mysborn
you and trespaced vnto me /

yet for asmykyl as I se your
grete humilite

And that ye be sory and repentaunt of
youre giltes

hit constrayneth me to do you grace and
mercy /
wherfore I receue you to my grace

and forgeue
you vtterly alle the offences . Iniuryes and wronges that
ye haue done ayenst me .

to this effect and to this ende
that god of his endles mercy

wille at the day of my dy-
ynge forgyuie me my giltes that I haue trespaced to hy
in this world /

For doutles yf we be sory and repentant
for our synnes and giltes / the sight of oure lorde god

is
so fre and so mercyable
that he wil forgyue vs our giltꝭes
and brynge vs to the blysse that neuyr shale haue ende amēm

ab.hi: ere endeth Chaucers tale of Mel-lebe and prudence his wiff and Sophie his doughter

div.l: ¶ ⁊and begynneth
the Monkes Prologe // ~~ ~~ ~~
Whanne endid was the tale of Mellebe
And of Prudence and of hir benignyte
Oure hoste seide ʆser/sir as i am feithfulle manne //.
And by the precious corpus Madrian
I had leuir than a barelle of Ale .
That good leff my wiff had herde this tale .
For she is nothynge of suche pacience .
As was this Mellebeus wiff prudence .
Be goddis bonys when I bete my knauys
She bryngeth me the grete clobbed stauys .
And cryeth sle the dogges euerychone .
And breke both backe and also bone .
And yf that eny neyghbore of myne
Wol not in churche to my wiff enclyne
Or be so hardy to hir trespas .
Whan she cōmmeth home she rampeth in my face
And cryed fals coward wreke thy wyff
Be corpus dıı̄uns I wille haue thy knyff
And thou shalt haue my distaff and go spynne
Fro day to nyght she wol thus begynne .
Allas she seyth that euyr I was shape .
To wed a mylkesop a cowarde ape
That wolbe ouyr led wᵗith euery wight
Thou darst not stonde be thy wiff a right
This is my lyff but yf that I wold fight
And out at dore anone I must me dight
And ellis I am lost but yf that I
Be like awilde lyon foole hardy
I wote welle she wol do me sle som day
Som neyghbore and than go my wey
For I am ꝑper/parlous with knyfe in honde .
Al be it that I . dar not hir wistonde
For she is bigge in armys be my feith .
That shalle he fynde . that hir mysdoth and seith
But let vs passe . awey from this matere
My lorde sir monke he seith be mery of chere .
For ye shulle tellyn a tale truly //
Lo Rochestre stondith here fast by
Ryde forth myn owne lorde breke not our game
But be my trouth I knowe not your name
Whodir shalle I calle you my lorde dan Iohn
Or dane thomas / dan Robert or dan Albone
Or of whate hous be ye by youre fadir kynne
I vowe to god thou haste a ful feir chynne
Hit is a gentille pasture there thou gost
Thou art lyke not a penaunt goste
Vpon my feith thou art som officere
Som worthy sexten or som celerere
For be my Fadir soule as to my dome
Thou art a maister whan thou art at home
No pore cloysterer ne no pore nouyce
But a gouernour wily and wyse
And therwᵗith of brawen and of bonys
A wolle farynge ꝑper/parsone for the nonys
I pray to god yeue hym confucion .
That firste the brought in to religion
Thou woldist haue be a tredefoule aright
Haddist thou as grete leue as thou hast myght
To ꝑper/parforme alle thy luste in gendrure
Tho haddist begoten many a creature
Allas why werist thou to wide a cope
God yeue me sorowe and I were pope
Not only thou but euery myghty man .
Though he were shore vpon his pan .
Shuld haue a wiff for alle this world is lorn
Religiou hath taken vp alle the corn
Of tredynge and borel men . be shrympes
Of febille treys ther cometh wreched ympes
This maketh that oure heires be so sklendir
And febil that they may not wel engendre
This maketh our wyuys wolle assay
Religious folke for they may bettir Pay
Of venus paymentes than mowe we
God wode no lusshburghs pay ye
But be not wroth my lorde though I play
Fol ofte in game a soth haue I herde sey
Thys worthy monke took al in pacience
And seyde I wille do my dili diligence
As fer as sowneth vnto honeste
To telle you a tale or two or thre
And yf you lyste to herken hedirward
I wille ʆser/sir you sey of the lyff of seynt Edward
Or elles tragedies first wolle I telle
Of whiche I haue and hundred in my selle
Tregedy is for to telle a certeyn story
As old bokes maken memory
Of hem that stondyn in grete prosꝑper/parite
And is fal out of his degre
In to mysery and endith wrechedly
And they bene versified comonly
Of . vj . fete whiche mēm clepen exametron
In prose eke ben endited many on
And in metre many asondry wyse
Lo this ought ynowe to suffice
Nowe herkeneth yf you lyst fro to here
But first I beseche you in this matere
Though I be ordre telle not this thyngis
Be hit of popes Emꝑper/parours or kynges
And aftir her agis as men written fynde
But telle hem som before and som behynde
As hit cometh to my remembraunce
Haue me excuced of myn ignoraunce .
Here endeth the monkes prologe
And begynneth the monkes tale
I wille bewayle on maner of tregedie
The harme of hem that stovden in hie degre
And fillen so that ther nas no remedye
To brynge hem out of her Aduersite .
For certen when that fortune lyst to fle
There may nomām of her the cours wilholde
Many amām ovir throwen hath she .
Beth ware be this ensample yonge and olde
Lucifer though he an angel were
And nat a mām at hym I wil begynne
For thy fortune may not angil dere
From high degre yet fil he for his synne
Doun in to helle where he is yet ynne
O lucifer brightest of angels alle
Nowe art thou Sathanas that mayst not twyn
Out of mysery whiche thou art falle
Lo Adam on þᵉ feilds of Damasce
No fr gods owne finger wrought was h
And not begottēm of mans spirme vncle
And will all paradice saving o tre
Neủer/re wordlie man had so hie degree
As Adam / till he for misgouernanc
Was dryven out of his high prospe
To Labour / ⁊and to hill ⁊and to mischaunse
Lo sampson whiche was anıı̄unciat
By the angele longe or his natyuyte
And was to god almyghty consecrate
And stode in nobles whylys he myght se
Was neuyr suche anothir as was he
To speke of strengthe and therto hardynes .
But to his wyues tolde he his secrete .
Through whiche he slewe hym selfe for wrechednes
Sampson this noble and myghty champion .
Withouten wepen saue his hondis twey
He slough and alle to rent the lyoun
Taward his weddynge walkynge by the wey
His fals wiff coude hym pleace and prey
Til she his councelle knewe and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos his councel gan bewrey
And hym forsoke and toke anothir newe
And houndred foxes toke Sampson for Ire
And alle her tailles he togedir bonde .
And set the Foxes tailles al on fiere
For he on euery taille hath put a bronde
And they brent alle the cornes in that londe .
And her Olyues and her vynes eke
A thousand men eke he slewe wᵗith his honde
And had no wepyn wᵗith hym but an asse cheke
Whan they were slayne so thristed hym that he
Was wel nygh loren for whiche he gan to pᵃy
That god wold of his peyne haue som pite
And sende hym drynke or elles Must he deye
And of an asse cheke that was so drye
Out of a wange touth sprange anone awelle
Of whiche he dranke Inough shortly to sey
Thus halpe hym god as Iudicıı̄un can telle
Be verey force at gasa on a nyght
Magre alle the phelistenes of that Cite
The gates of the toun he vp plight
And on his bak y caried hem hath he
High vpon a hille where as men myght se
O noble and myghty Sampson leef and dere
That stronge worthy and noble haue be
In alle this world ne hath be no þⁱ pere
This Sampson neythir sidir dranke ne wyne
Ne on his hede cam rasour non ne shere
Be pcept of the Messynger dyuyne
For alle his strenthe was in his here
Of his strength he had no pere
And xv yere
of Israel he had the goủer/renaunce
But aftir sone shalle he wepe many a teer
For a womām brought hym to myschaunce
Vnto his lemmām Dalida he tolde
That in his herys alle his strength lay
And falsely to his foes hym she solde .
And slepynge vppon a barm vppon a day
They made to clippe or shere his his here awey
And made his fomēm alle his craft aspien .
And when that they hym fonde in suche aray
They bonde hym firste and put out his eyen
But or his here were clipped or shaue
Ther was no bonde that myght hym bynde
But nowe is he put in pⁱrison in a Caue
Where as they made hym at quyrne grynde
O noble Sampson strengest of man kynde
O whilom Iuge in glorie and riches
Yet nevir lyke to the I fynde
Sith thou art from wele falle in to wrechednes
The ende of this caitif was as I shalle sey
His fomēm made a feste vppon a day
And made hym there before hem pley
And this was in a temple of grete array
But at laste he made a foule fray
For he two postes shoke and made hem falle
And doun fil the temple and alle there lay
And slough hym selfe and eke his fomēm alle
This is to sey the prynces euerichone
And eke a thousand bodyes were the slayne
With fallynge of the grete tempil of stone
Of Sampson wol I nomore seyn .
Beth ware of this ensample old and playne
That nomām tel her councel to her wyves
Of suche thynge as they wold haue secrete fayn
Yf that hit touche her lymes or her lyues
Of Hercules the souerayne conqueroure
Syngynge his workes loude ⁊and high renoun
For in his tyme of strengthe he bare the flour
He sleugh and rafte the skynne of the Lyoun
And of Centaurus leyde he the bost a doun
He Arpies sleugh the cruel briddis felle
He the golden apples raft fro the dragoun
He drewe out Cerberus the hound of helle
He sleugh the cruel tiraunt busurus
And made his hors to frete hym fleysh ⁊and bone
He sleugh the vere serpent venemous
Of Achilles two hornes brake he one
And he sleugh Cakus in a Caue of stone
He sleugh the Geant Antheus the stronge
He sleugh the grysly beor and that anone
He bare his hede vpon his spere longe
Was nevir wight sith the world begane
That sleugh so many monstris as did he
Through the wide world his name ran .
Whate for his strengthe and his bounte
And euery reame went he for to se
He was so stronge that nomām myght hy lett
And both worldis endis seith Tymothe
In stede of bondes he of bras a piler sett
A lemmām had this noble champioun
That hight deyanyra as freyshe as may
And as klerkes make mencion
She hath hym sent a shert freysh and gay
Allas this short and wel awey
Envenomed was and subtilly wᵗith alle
That er he had werid hit halfe aday
Hit made his fleysh fro his bones falle
But natheles som clerkes hir excusen .
Be on that hight nessus that hit maked
Be as be may I wolnot hir accusen .
But on his body the shert he werid al naked
Tille the fleysh was for the venyme slakid
And when he sawe no nonothir remedy
In hote colys he hath hym selfe raked
For with no venyme deyned he not to dy
Thus starf this worthy myghty hercules
Lo who may trust in fortune eny throwe
For hym that foloweth al this world of prees
Or he be ware is ofte leide fulle lowe .
Ful wise is he that hym silfe can knowe
Be ware for when that fortune list to glose
Then waiteth she hir mām doun to throwe
Be suche awey as he wold lest suppose
THe myghti trone the precoıı̄uns tresure
The gracious septre and the ryal magiste
That had the kynge Nabugodonosor
With tonge vnneth may discrybed be
He tweyes wan Ierusalem the Cite
The vessel of the temple he wᵗith hym lad
At Babylon was his souerayn see
In whiche his glory and his delite he had
The feirest child of the blode royal
Of Ierusalem he dede to gelde anone
And made eche of hem to be his thral
Amonge al othir Danyel was one
That was the wiseste child of euerychone
For he the dremes of the kynge exponede
There as in Caldey clerkes was there none
That wiste to whate fyne his dremes sowned
This proud kynge let make a statu of gold
Sixty Cubitis longe and seuyn in brede /
Of whiche ymage both yonge and olde
Commaundid he to lote and haue in drede
Or in a furneys ful of flames rede
He shuld be ded that a woldnot obey
But nevir wold he Accorde to that dede

Whan that hir housbande had lost his lyfe

She was so fulle of turment and rage

O wofulle hennes so that cryden ye
As whan that nero brent the Cite

For that her housbandis shulde lose her lyuys

Nowe wolle I turne to my tale ageyne
This sely wedowe and hir doughtirs two
Herden the hennys crye and make wo
And out at the dore stert they anone
And sawe the foxe tawarde the wo gone
And bare vppon his backe the cock awey
And cryden out and harowe and welawey
A ha the foxe and aftir hym they renne
And eke with staues many othir menne
Ren col our dogge talbot and garlonde
And malkyn wᵗith hir distaf in hir honde
Ran cow and eke the very hogges
For they so sore a ferde were of the dogges
And showtynge of mēm and womēm eke
They ron so her hert thought to to breke
They yellen as fendis don in helle
The dogges criden as mēm wold hem quelle
Out of the hyues come the swarme bees
The gees for fere fley ouer the trees
So hidous was the noyse a benedicite
Certis Iacke strawe ne his meyne
Ne made nouyr showtes halfe so shrille
Whan that they wolde ony flemynge kylle
As that day was made vpon the foxe
Of bras they blewe trumpes and of boxe
Of horne of bone in whiche the powpid
And ther wᵗith they shryked and showtid
Hit semed as though heuēm shuld falle
Nowe good mēm I pray you herken alle
Lo howe fortune turneth sodenly
The hope and the pride of her enuy
This cok that lay vpon the foxe bak
In alle his drede vnto the fox he spak
And seide sir yf I were as ye
Yet shuld I sey as wys god hepe me
Turneth ayen ye proude churles alle
A vere pestilence vpon you alle
Nowe am I come vnto this wodis side
Magre youre hed the cok shal here abide
I wolle hym ete in feith and that anone
The foxe answerde in feith hit shalbe done
And as he spake the worde all sodenly
This cok brake from his mouth delyuerly
And high vpon a tre he fley anone
And when the foxe sawe that he was gone .
Allas quod he o chauniteclere Allas /
I haue do to you grete trespas
In asmoche as I make you a ferde
When I you hent and brought out of youre yerde
But sir I did hit not in no wicked entent
Come done and I shalle telle you whate I ment
I shalle you say soth so god helpe me so
Nay than quod he I shrewe vs both two
And firste I shrewe my selfe both blode ⁊and bonys
Yf thou begile me ofter than onys
Thou shalt nomore with thy flatrye
Do me synge with awynkynge eye
For he that wynketh whan he shulde se
As wysly god let hym nevir the
Nay quod the foxe god yeue hym myschaᵃunce
That is so vndiscrete of gouernaᵃunce
That Iangelith whan that he shuld haue pees
Lo suche is it for to be recheles
And necligent and truste on flaterye
But ye that holden thys tale a folye
As of a foxe and a cok and an henne
Taketh the moralite good menne
For seynt Poule seith alle that wrytten ys
To oure doctryne is wrytten ywys
Taketh the frute and let the chaf be stille
Nowe good mēm yf that hit be youre wille
As seith my lorde so make vs all good men
And brynge vs to his blys high blis amēm

I pray to god so yeue hym right good chaunce

Be what thou be breke not our pley

For truly methynketh be thy chere

Telle afabil anone for cockes bonys

Thou getist fabil non tolde for me
For poule that wrytteth to Tymothe
Repreueth hem that veyuen sothfastnes
And techen fablis and suche wrechednes
Why shuld I sowe draff out of my fyste
Whan I may sowe whete yf me lyste
For whiche I sey yf that thou lyst to here
Moralite and of vertuous matere
And then yf ye wolle ye me Audience
I wolde fulfayne at cristes reuerence
Done you plesaunce leeffulle as I am .
But trusteth wel I am a sotheryn man
I cannot geste rum ram ruf by letter
And god wote ryme hold I but litle bettir
And therfore yf ye luste I wol not glose
I wolle you telle . a mery tale in prose
To knytt vp alle this fest and make an ende
And Ihu for his grace witt me sende
To showe you the wey in this viage
Of that ilke ꝑper/parfitt gloryus pilgremage
That hight Ierusalem celestialle
And yf ye vouchesafe anone I shal .
Begynne vpon my tale for whiche I prey
Tel youre avise I can no bettir seye
But natheles this meditacouı
I put hit ay vndir correccioun
Of clerkes for I am not textuelle
I take but the sentence trustith welle
Therfore I make protestaciouı
That I wol stonde to correccioun
Vpon this worde we haue ascented sone
For as hit semede hit was forto done
To enden in som vertuous sentence
And for to yeue hym place audience
And bade to oure hoste he sholde to hym sey
That alle we to telle his tale hym prey
Our oste haste the wordes for vs alle
